SPEECH.PARA: Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for its grave failure in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against the tax laws resulting in multi-billion dollar frauds against the Commonwealth.

Yesterday, the Government tabled in this Parliament Interim Report No. 4 Volume 1 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. In the subsequent period, the Opposition has had the opportunity of considering in detail the implications of that report. The consequence of that is that it is our conviction that we have no choice but to move a censure against the Government. It is clear from the information disclosed in that report that the responsibility for incompetence in administration goes well beyond those people who are dealt with directly by the Royal Commission's report . In the final result, it is quite apparent that there has been a serious irresponsibility in the discharge of ministerial duties by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). Because of their association with the Government through Cabinet in the discharge of their responsibilities, the Government must finally accept responsibility in this matter.

I want to put one thing on the record clearly from the start. Insofar as this report or any previous or succeeding reports of this Royal Commission disclose activities by members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which are criminal activities, which are offences against the civil law of this land, we sincerely trust that the full force of the law will fall upon those people without delay. We waste no time in seeking in any way to justify behaviour which we would find and do find, to the extent that it has been reported so far, totally unacceptable.

I commence by referring to what obviously will be the main thrust of the defence of the Government in seeking to protect the indolent behaviour of both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General in this matter. There is no doubt that reference will be made to section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-the secrecy provisions, as they are referred to-as a justification for that dilatoriness on the part of those two ministerial gentlemen. Mr Costigan, the Royal Commissioner, very properly points out that, to the extent that that section has been interpreted as a secrecy section, it has been interpreted too narrowly. It certainly is a privacy section but not a secrecy section. But even on a tough literal interpretation of the wording of that section it is quite clear that information of a general nature which becomes available to the Australian Taxation Office in the course of matters related to a particular person is not prohibited from being conveyed to the responsible Minister. Sub- section (5A) of that section, which refers to prohibition, states:

For the purposes of sub-sections (2) and (5) . . . an officer or person shall be deemed to have communicated such information to another person in contravention of those sub-sections if he communicates that information to any Minister, or to any Minister of the Crown of a State.

That is fine. But the sub-section refers to information concerning the affairs of any other person, as a direct quote. In other words, given the extent to which the Taxation Office, in the course of its investigations, established general behaviour in the community designed to flout-criminally flout-the law and the extent to which opinions with general application became available to the Taxation Office which clearly evidenced that existing law could be applied, and applied effectively in such cases, that information could quite clearly be conveyed to the Attorney-General and to the Treasurer and, of course, passed on to the Government. Insofar as those general matters arise-it is on the basis of a serious dereliction of duty on the part of both the Treasurer and the Attorney -General in respect of those general matters- there is no defence for the Treasurer, the Attorney-General or the Government in trying to hide behind the veil of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Superficially, it would seem from the rather bland statement delivered in this Parliament yesterday by a rather bland Minister that the Government had undertaken action in response to the findings of Commissioner Costigan- superficially. Certainly the establishment of a national crimes commission has reared its head again. Certainly there is the proposal for a special prosecutor and a task force to investigate those matters disclosed by Commissioner Costigan to establish what evidence is necessary now to proceed in the courts. Certainly two lower level officers of a very incompetent office of the Crown Solicitor's Division have been suspended and, admittedly, there is to be an external examination of that office in Western Australia and a review of the office.

Those and some other matters are attended to. But the report goes well beyond that. The incompetence or, indeed, probably much worse than that went right to the top of the Crown Solicitor's Division in the period attended to by this report, and that period was the period during which tax evasion sky-rocketed in this country. I ask honourable members to dwell on those words for a few seconds -tax evasion, not tax avoidance. Tax evasion has always been a criminal offence. Tax avoidance is the practice someone adopts to get around the spirit of a law when there are gaps in the drafting of that law. But tax evasion is activity undertaken consciously to avoid legal responsibility under particular laws; that is, a criminal offence. That is what this reports talks about.

I think it ought to go on record also that the disclosures of these matters in relation to tax evasion are not the core of what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was seeking to pursue when he set up this Royal Commission. He was off on a fishing trip against the Painters and Dockers Union. He had a shotgun aimed at the union and it blew up in his face. The only reason these matters are now being reported to the Parliament, to the people of this country, is that Commissioner Costigan in his investigations established that it would be necessary to go far beyond the skimpy and limited terms of reference that the Government had given him. The terms were limited to an inquiry as to whether the union or its members had engaged in illegal activities in relation to shipping or any naval establishment. It has gone well beyond that. It has become a royal commission of inquiry into aspects of tax evasion in this country.

The Prime Minister is a belated and frankly reluctant convert to sheeting home responsibility on this matter. I ask honourable members to recall the 1980 election when the Treasurer and the Prime Minister heaped scorn on the Australian Labor Party, and those like us who are morally outraged, when we denounced the tax evasion and tax avoidance which was going on in this country. The Treasurer now has the gall to stand up on any public platform he can grab and declare that his Government, and he as Treasurer, have done more to combat tax avoidance and evasion than any previous government. I have to confess-my colleagues will agree with me-that they have had more opportunity to do more than any previous government because there has been more tax evasion and tax avoidance under their Government than any other government in the history of this country.

The Treasurer and his colleagues are exposed by this report, as they were exposed by the McCabe-Lafranchi report, as sham fighters when it comes to this matter. How fair dinkum is the Treasurer when he stands here, or on any public platform that is prepared to bear the weight of his hypocrisy, and says that his Government will apply fierce action where tax avoidance and tax evasion are concerned? It took him two and a half years from when he was aware that there was need for action in relation to tax evasion and avoidance until the introduction of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. Four years ago the Treasurer said that he would act against the underground economy. He only did it in this Budget with public pressure. Four years ago he said that he would act against overseas tax havens which were ripping off Australian taxpayers on a massive scale and he still has not done anything. How much credibility has he got when, seeking to rebut the McCabe-Lafranchi report which exposed all of the hypocrisy and dilatoriness of this Government on this issue, he resorted to this sort of claim? He stated:
Moreover, strong public attitudes towards tax avoidance were not yet evident at that time.
That was 1978. He went on:
. . . it is clearly important to recognise the considerably different state of public opinion towards tax avoidance than existed at that time.
In other words the Government was not prepared to do anything until the public forced it to. In a statement in relation to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes he says:
. . . there are only five identified cases of post-3 December 1980 company strips (none of them in Victoria), with no more than a possibility that others may exist.
I refer to page 89 of the Costigan report which states that there are 121 cases after the period the Treasurer is talking about. That is how fair dinkum he is.

The question of ministerial responsibility revolves around this issue: Did the Ministers know and ought they to have known? On any reasonable interpretation of the implications of Costigan's report one concludes, in relation to the first, that the Ministers certainly should have known if they were competent, if they diligently discharged their duties, and therefore one expects that they did know . If they did not know, in relation to the second matter, they were extraordinarily reckless where their duties were concerned.

To discuss that matter we have to put it in a sequential framework and one refers to the developments which are outlined in the report. Todman, a senior investigator in Western Australia with the Taxation Office, carried out what is described in quite generous and respectful professional terms by Costigan as an investigation which, as I said, established in relation to one promoter-I stress that it was one promoter alone; that is all that Costigan was looking at in this report-that certain tax evasion measures were proliferating. Todman at that point in 1975 was suspicious of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Western Australia. It was a suspicion on behalf of the Taxation Office which, by the nature of responsible, concerned bureaucrats, would have been conveyed to his seniors in the Taxation Office. As a consequence of that-we are not given the reasons for this suspicion although they are abundantly clear from reading between the lines as we go through the report-in January 1975 a Queen's Counsel named Brinsden, who is now a judge of the Supreme Court in Western Australia, declared two things: Firstly, that existing legal provisions in criminal and civil law were adequate to proceed against this particular promoter and those associates of his involved in these tax evasion measures and, secondly, that there was sufficient evidence to anticipate a conviction.

In November 1975 the decision was given to proceed with the prosecution and thereafter the process became embalmed. In 1976 a second opinion, from a Sydney silk, was provided. Subsequently, in that year a very competently compiled police report was presented pointing out, as did the second Queen's Counsel's opinion, that what Brinsden had declared was correct. The police report established, in terms glowingly described by Costigan which reflected the competence of that report, that there was sufficient evidence to proceed and expect a conviction. As I said before, the case became embalmed. It became embalmed for two to three years. This was in spite of the fact that Brinsden took the precaution of sending his opinion direct to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia and to the Commissioner of Taxation here in Canberra. So within the Taxation Office at the highest level people were already informed of this opinion.

The Taxation Office identified this as a test case. It represented an extra large fraud. Let me refer to the dimensions of the fraud which went on under the dilatoriness of this Government. If we accept in current day terms that tax evasion-putting avoidance to one side-is in excess of $3,000m a year and if these practices went on because of the lassitudinal responses of the Government in the past five to seven years, we are looking at a fraud perpetrated against Australian taxpayers of the order of $10,000m to $15,000m. That is the order of the fraud which has been tolerated and accommodated by the incompetence, the reckless irresponsibility, of these two Ministers and the Government. The Taxation Office sought to have the case given priority. Page 40 of Costigan's report pointed out that the amount to be collected in any other case was a pittance compared with this case. In 1978 the Crown Solicitor was made aware by the Taxation Office of all of these circumstances. In 1979 the Crown Solicitor's Office in Canberra became alarmed and then suddenly became frozen over by the Perth stone walling. All of this was taking place with the people at the highest order in the Taxation Office and at the highest level in the Crown Solicitor's Office being aware of all of these circumstances.

I refuse to believe-from my experience as a Minister and more particularly when these things were happening in 1978, 1979 and 1980 when tax avoidance and tax evasion were being made major issues of controversy in this country by the Opposition attacking this conservative Government-that any responsible Minister would fail to explore in all of its ramifications, in all of its finest details, firstly, the capability of applying existing law effectively against offenders in this area, and, secondly, if there was a defectiveness what action should be taken and taken properly. As part and parcel of that sort of initiative I would expect any responsible officer to ask: What opinions do we have? What is existing law? What is case law in these matters?

The senior law officer of the land is the Attorney-General. He is, in his own right, a highly qualified and formerly practising lawyer. His responsibility is not to be a paper shuffler, not to accept the oral reassurances of people in his Department; for in the final result the responsibility for the interpretation of laws in these matters rests with him. He accepts the penalties that flow from incompetence or inadequate attention being given to those responsibilities. He, in his own right and by his qualifications, should have explored all of those provisions of existing laws and explored the implications of all those available legal opinions. He should, by his own experience, know that the generalists in his Department-it is obvious from this report that they are in too many cases vastly underqualified and inexperienced for the job they have-cannot provide him with the sort of conviction in opinions that a specialist at the Bar can provide .

In all those circumstances there is something very smelly indeed going on for the Treasurer and the Attorney-General to argue that they were not aware of the strange set of complications which was under way. The Taxation Office in fact felt that there was something very smelly involved in all of this. Let me quote from page 67 of Costigan's report. It states:
. . . Legal Officers in the Taxation Office who generally could not understand why the existing law was not being used to redress the situation.

He was saying that legal officers in the Taxation Office were, at the very least , sceptical of the reluctance to apply existing laws in respect of those matters which were the subject of his report. That is a very interesting quotation because it is at odds with the statement of the Treasurer in his 27 June 1982 Press release responding to and seeking to discredit the McCabe-Lafranchi report . In relation to that matter he said:
. . . the Taxation Office did not simply ask for advice and receive it-having received unfavourable advice it pressed the matter with its legal advisers,--
That is, in its own Office-
only to have that advice confirmed.

There, on the evidence of what Costigan says, is the evidence that that statement is not truthful. The legal advisers within the Taxation Office believed clearly, on the explicit statements of Costigan, that existing law was more than adequate with which to proceed against this promoter and his associates. More than that, they had available to them not only their own legal department to interpret the law but also the opinion of Brinsden at least.

But I think that parenthetically we ought to recognise one other factor. In all of Costigan's report what is abundantly clear is simply this: For all of the obfuscation, the foot dragging, the tactics designed to deflect a proper course of justice in this matter at various levels within the bureaucracy and the Crown Solicitor's Office, none of the people involved in those deflecting activities ever challenged the applicability of existing law. To the extent that they sought to deflect they sought to do so solely on the basis that sufficient evidence was not available. All I can say is that we must have in the Treasurer and the Attorney-General two of the most incurious Ministers we have ever seen in government in this country.

When the issue of tax avoidance and evasion has reached white heat in this country, which it has progressively through 1978, 1979 and 1980, and when the Taxation Office and the Crown Solicitor's Office have before them senior counsel 's opinions-not just one or two but many-to the effect that existing law can be applied and that in specific cases there is sufficient evidence to proceed with every reasonable expectation of a conviction being obtained, does anyone believe that when consultation takes place between the Attorney-General and his law officers and between the Treasurer and his taxation people, they do not say to those Ministers: 'Look, we have had these opinions from senior sources. They tell us that in fact we can proceed. There is something funny going on there in the distant reaches of this vast continent and we are exploring this'? Surely there is a responsibility upon the Attorney-General to explore, in all their ramifications, the varying opinions before him, even the shonky ones from the outpost in Perth and, if he is not satisfied, if he is unconvinced, to obtain independent judgment from outside the bureaucracy, from the practising Bar.

No one will be convinced that these Ministers discharged their responsibilities properly. We all know and the Australian public knows that this Government is a sham fighter when it comes to the issue of tax evasion and tax avoidance. The Treasurer postures in the Parliament, trying to demolish the credibility of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and saying that tax avoidance is now a dead issue. The McCabe-Lafranchi report stated, as the opinions available to the Government did, not only that existing laws were sufficient to sheet home responsibility but also that in Victoria companies were still being registered at the rate of 35, 000 a year or fifty to sixty a week. The Government must be in a perpetual sleep . There is a vast range of existing laws. There is case law which goes back to the eighteenth century and which quite clearly is applicable in these matters. It has been oulined in Costigan's report and referred to in the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Surely that knowledge of law is not beyond the wit and wisdom of the Public Service. Surely the Attorney-General, as our first law officer in the land, and the Treasurer himself, as a qualified solicitor, would not remain incurious when these basic principles, practices and provisions of the law are so widely and well known. Surely these matters would have been brought before their attention in the course of discussion in relation to what changes should take place in the law.

Obviously, on the basis of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and Costigan's latest report there is no need for a change of law. There is no need for retrospectivity at all. All we need is a bit of guts and determination from the Government to get the crooks who are ripping off. Let us look at the long list of opinions, most of which are quoted in the Costigan report. There is the Brinsden Q.C. opinion in 1975. There is an unnamed Sydney silk's opinion in 1976 . There are the opinions of Ormiston and Spry in 1978. There is the opinion of Traill Q.C. in 1978. There is a 1978 opinion which my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) has quoted from several times in this House. On top of that, there is the opinion of the legal department of the Taxation Office and there is also the very competently presented report of senior investigator Todman. They are all saying the same thing and they are saying it very positively. The Government could have acted if it had wanted to act. Finally, there is the police report which makes it clear that the Government could have approached the prospect of proceedings with confidence that they would be successful. I refuse to believe that our bureaucracy and the Taxation Office are so reckless to their responsibilities that they would never have discussed any of these crucial matters with the Treasurer in the course of discussing the weaknesses in the law that he saw.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happened when you were Treasurer.

—In November 1975, my friend, authority was given to proceed with prosecution. The processes became embalmed under a shonky government in Western Australia where the State branch of the Liberal Party is controlled by criminal tax evaders. Do not lecture me!

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make a couple of other relevant points. This report refers to one promoter only operating through Perth. What of the other promoters in other capital cities? What of the promoters in the bailiwick of the Treasurer, Sydney and Melbourne? They are innumerable. On page 2 of this report Costigan says that he has in transit a semi-trailer load and a container load of papers relevant to these matters. It is quite obvious that more opinions are available from eminent counsel than I have quoted. I have outlined six, in addition to one from the legal section of the Taxation Office. The fact is that a massive tax rort has been going on for ages.

Pages 90 and 91 of this report make it clear that the evidence should have been quite patently apparent to the Treasurer. They show that, although company registrations were sky-rocketing, the tax paid was diminishing while the proportion of tax being paid by income earners was sky-rocketing. My colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has made that a key thrust in debate in this House on many occasions. The conclusion is obvious: The Government, by its irresponsibility, has shifted a major share or load of the tax burden on to wage and salary earners so that these tax thieves, these tax cheats, can rip off at the expense of the rest of the community. The Treasurer and the Attorney-General have been reckless to their responsibilities. They should have known. Quite frankly, from my experience with people in the Taxation Office, I believe the Treasurer would have known. Perhaps more than that: On being briefed on these matters and being committed to them, the Treasurer and the Attorney-General have to convince Cabinet. If they convince Cabinet after discussing all of these matters, which is the proper way, the Cabinet also is irresponsible to its duty because it has failed to address itself to this plethora of opinion and existing law that could have sheeted home responsibility . Let not the Prime Minister seek to wriggle his way out of this. In 1972 he said:

But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia , and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

That goes beyond the principle of ministerial responsibility that I enunciate. But the principle I enunciate has been seriously breached by both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General with the backing of the Government. The Government deserves to be censured and condemned for the way it has allowed a $10,000m to $ 15,000m fraud to go on for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I warmly second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! All honourable members on my left will remain silent. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that, while the Leader of the Opposition was speaking to his motion of censure, the great bulk of the noise in the chamber was from his own side. —The Government rejects the censure motion. It does so not because the matters disclosed in the Costigan report are not matters of the gravest seriousness and not because the allegations contained in the conclusions of that report do not require the most vigorous examination, investigation and, where necessary, prosecution of the people who committed criminal wrong-doing at the time those events took place nor the most vigorous action to collect for the people of Australia the amount of tax that was illegally evaded. The Government rejects this motion by the Opposition because it is falsely based. It comes from the mouth of somebody who, when he was Treasurer of this country, failed to close the notorious Curran loophole, which was, after all, as most students of the growth of the tax avoidance industry in this country know, the spur to the development of tax avoidance in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps more than that, the Government rejects this motion because it finds it very curiously based upon the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. In dealing with that aspect I remind the House that both of the reports which have featured in the tax avoidance and tax evasion debate of the last few months were commissioned by Liberal governments. The Victorian report was commissioned by the former Liberal Government of Mr Thompson. The Costigan report was commissioned by this Government--
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the House and especially the honourable members for Hotham and Hindmarsh that in this chamber if a man is under attack he is entitled to answer and be heard in silence. I call upon the honourable members for Hindmarsh and Hotham to act according to the democratic process and listen.

—The Government established the Costigan Royal Commission, it courageously extended the terms of reference and it widened the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. At all times the Government has been prepared to allow the findings in the Costigan report to fall where they may and to see that those recommended for prosecution are so recommended without fear or favour. The fact is that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has based much of his criticism of me and of my colleague the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) on the proposition that at all material times we knew what was going on. That is the charge that has been made by the Leader of the Opposition. He repeated it and he even drew on his own experience when he was Treasurer of this country. If he recalls that experience he will know the nature of the administrative responsibilities of the Australian Taxation Office under the Income Tax Assessment Act. He will know the nature of the secrecy provisions of the Act. He will know the great and proper importance attached by the officers of the Australian Taxation Office to the preservation of confidentiality and secrecy.

SPEECH.PARA: I say without any equivocation that I have the highest personal regard for the integrity and the zeal of the officers of the Australian Taxation Office. They have been the subject of criticism and vilification and I do not resile one bit from some of the things that I said in reply to the McCabe-Lafranchi report. But that respect and that regard should not blind us to facts. It ought not to blind the Leader of the Opposition to the very simple fact that the premise of his own argument contradicts his principal claim. He is saying that we knew all the time what was going on, yet one of the major findings in the Costigan report is that the Income Tax Assessment Act is so structured that we cannot find out what is going on. I find the proposition of the Leader of the Opposition to be a very remarkable one. On page 95 of the Costigan report it is stated:

It is essential that the Treasurer of the Commonwealth . . . should be able to gain full access to taxation information so that he can see the extent to which the revenue of the Commonwealth may be being affected by fiscal policy or by the depredations of thieves and rogues.

That is the finding of Costigan himself. He wrote those words because he believed that the present structure of the Act did not enable that full and proper information to be obtained. Now, there are things about the secrecy provisions of the Act that I do not want to see changed and that no responsible democratic government would want to see changed. I do not want to see a situation where the Treasurer of this country, whoever he may be, has access to individuals' personal taxation files. So the principal charge of the Leader of the Opposition-that is, that I either knew or I ought to have known-is not just contradicted by me or contradicted by the Attorney-General; it is contradicted by Costigan himself. One of his principal findings was that the situation has to be changed so that the Treasurer of the Commonwealth shall be able to gain full access to taxation information, so that he can see the extent to which the revenue of the Commonwealth may be being affected by fiscal policy or by the depredations of thieves and rogues. What Costigan is saying here-if the plain, ordinary English language means anything-is that as things stand at present that facility is not available. Therefore, I find it rather strange that the Leader of the Opposition should base his criticism of me, should base his call for my resignation, on a report that contradicts his basic premise.

Let me go back to the facts and the circumstances of this very, very unhappy matter-a matter of which we have not, as yet, seen the end. Let me remind the House of what I said when I introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in December 1970. On that occasion I said that the Government had decided to introduce that legislation because the advice that had been given to the Government by the Crown Solicitor, by the First Parliamentary Counsel and I think also the Attorney-General's Department, was to the effect that the existing law was not adequate to enable a successful prosecution to be brought. The nub of much of this debate is that Costigan says that that legal advice was wrong. That is what he says; he says it was wrong. Costigan is saying that the legal advice tendered to the Government by the Crown Solicitor, by the Attorney- General's Department and by the First Parliamentary Counsel in December 1980 and in the months leading up to the presentation of that Bill was wrong. I would have to say that events may well prove Mr Costigan wrong because until such time as the validity of prosecutions under the pre-1980 law is tested by the courts of this country, who is to know whether Mr Costigan is wrong? Who is to know that at the end of the day the highest court in this country will not, in fact, say: 'Mr Costigan, you were wrong. The advice tendered to the Government in December 1980 was correct and in fact it was only through the legislation passed in December 1980 that an effective end was brought to these particular schemes'. The future will in fact demonstrate whether that is the case. The only other thing that I want to say to this House on that particular subject is that whatever may be people's views about whether Costigan was right, the Crown Solicitor was right or the Solicitor-General was right, that particular legislation well and truly brought those practices to an end and was in fact a very, very effective piece of legislation.

Mr Speaker, I would like also to take the House back to 1978. I say to the House quite categorically that the first occasion that I knew that there was any contact between the Taxation Office and the Crown Solicitor's Office on this case was a three or four-line reference in a minute sent to me by the Commissioner of Taxation in May of 1978. He wrote:

In making this suggestion I mention that my officers have been pressing the Crown Solicitor to investigate whether prosecution action could be taken under the Crimes Act or the Companies Act against people involved in two cases of ' straw company' evasion. Despite the possibility that such prosecutions may be able to be launched I think that the specific taxation offence of the kind indicated should exist.

The specific taxation offence of which he was speaking was contained in his recommendation to me in May 1978, which I indicated in my reply to the McCabe- Lafranchi report, that there should be introduced into the criminal law of this country what ultimately became the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That was the first occasion. I do not mind saying to this House that that was an indication that was given to me. I say to the House and to those who have had experience of ministerial responsibility: Do those words indicate on their face that there has been a five-year period of frustration and delay between the Crown Solicitor and the Australian Taxation Office? Do those words on their face justify the charge that has been made against me by the Leader of the Opposition? The fact is that when the McCabe-Lafranchi report was filed in the Victorian Parliament, and I requested from the Australian Taxation Office a detailed commentary on the allegations contained in that report, there was made known to me for the first time-as indeed proved to be the case with the Attorney-General-the detail of the correspondence, the delay and the frustration and all of the things that have been criticised in the Costigan report. Those were made known for the first time by the Australian Taxation Office in the advice that it gave to me to enable the preparation of a reply to the McCabe-Lafranchi report.

I have not sought to disguise the chapter of events which flowed from the advice that was given to me and to the Government in 1978 that a criminal sanction of the kind embodied in the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act might be required. A period of 2 1/2 years then elapsed. I will tell the Leader of the Opposition and, with respect, Mr Costigan that one of the reasons why that period elapsed was that there were people in the Government who wondered whether this piece of legislation was necessary, which, of course, is the very argument that the Leader of the Opposition has used. In the final part of his remarks the Leader of the Opposition indicated that there was no need for that piece of legislation.

The fact of the matter is that in 1978 attitudes about tax avoidance in this country were indeed different. The Leader of the Opposition ought to go back through his own Question Time folder and the Question Time folder of the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) to find out how many times they raised the subject of tax avoidance in this Parliament. Let us go straight to the heart of this matter. We are censuring the Government. We are saying that the Government should resign. In terms of making the accusation that the Government has reached the point where resignation is necessary, it is essential to relate that to the issue before the House. Under seven years of this Government what have we, as Australians, witnessed? What has been the justification put forward by the apologists for this Government for those things which have happened?

Firstly, let us see, in fact, what has happened. Against all the promises that were made at the end of 1975 we have a rate of unemployment which has increased by 50 per cent. But what is most disastrous and most relevant to this motion is the fact that we have had the spread of poverty in this country-the doubling of poverty-to the extent that more than two million of our fellow Australians now live in identifiable poverty. That is what has happened. What has been the justification given by this Government for tolerating the emergence of two million people living in poverty? It has been this and simply this: That the Government has done all that it possibly can. It says that it has acquired all the financial capacity to do things for the underprivileged of this country that it possibly can.

What does this report, which is the basis of the censure motion, now reveal in response to that justification which has been put forward by the Government? The very essence of what this report shows is that if this Government had been about its business and if the Ministers directly involved in the relevant departments had been responsible and had discharged their responsibilities, there would have been available to this Government, during its life, an amount in excess of $10 billion. It is quite clear that if the Government, through its Ministers, had done its job properly we could have eliminated absolutely financial poverty in this country. That is what is at the guts of this censure motion.

The report shows that the dereliction of duty which has been engaged in by those Ministers and which has been endorsed by this Government is such that it has brought about that situation in Australia in which we have two million of our fellow Australians living in poverty. Alternatively, if the laws had been properly applied and the revenue of the Commonwealth had been assumed in the way that it should have been, that poverty could have been eliminated. There could not be any more substantial justification for a censure motion of this Government, which has been put forward by the Opposition, than what is involved in this matter. Clearly, the censure motion shows that if these Ministers and the Government had done what they should have done we could have eliminated poverty in this country. There could be no greater justification for a motion of this kind than that.

Let us look in more detail at the substantiation which is available on this matter. Before I do that let me make it quite clear, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) did in passing-he obviously could not spend much time upon it because he had to go over a great many matters-in respect of the substance of this report which deals with the trade union in issue, that the Opposition takes exactly the same view in respect of what is revealed in regard to that union and its members who have been engaged in criminal activity which warrants prosecution as it does in respect of those who have been engaged in tax evasion and other criminal activities associated with it. I suggest that it is a matter of some regret that the Government, in introducing this report, could find only vigorous language to use to direct against the unions. In the statement of the Minister for Communications and Minister Assisting the Attorney -General (Mr N.A. Brown) is a reference which states:

Volume 1 deals with the Commission's knowledge and findings on some aspects of the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, its members and persons associated with them. It describes a history of violence-
I ask honourable members to note this part particularly-
and the ruthless means by which members of the Union have arrogated to themselves a position outside the law.

To the extent that union members have done that and to the extent that their officials have been involved in it, the course of the law should be pursued. But is it not a matter of enormous pity that the Minister, in introducing this matter, and the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the other members speaking on behalf of the Government today, could not have mounted some of the same enthusiasm of language in talking about the tax evaders and those sustaining them in a way in which those people-to quote the Minister-'have arrogated to themselves a position outside the law'?

Let us come to the guts of the only defence which has been put forward to the charges that have been advanced by the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the other speakers on this side of the House. There is a pathetic attempt, echoed by the last speaker the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), that really it is all to be excused on the basis of that little section in the Income Tax Assessment Act- section 16. The last speaker has challenged us by asking: 'If you look at the report can you find anything at all in it which will overcome that sort of defence which you have put forward? If honourable members opposite had had the intelligence and the perspicacity but, more importantly, the desire to read the report they certainly could have found the answer to the question they put forward. They only had to go to the preceding paragraph and I direct their attention to it. The Prime Minister quoted from paragraph 3.10. It is best that it be put entirely in its context. This is the paragraph which the last speaker wanted us to go to. The paragraph reads:

It is necessary, before I proceed further, to draw the attention of those who may read this Report to the circumstance that the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act apply with equal force to the Ministers who have charge of the enforcement of the law in this area. I refer in particular-
Said Commissioner Costigan-

to persons holding the office of Treasurer, and of Attorney General. The events to which I am referring took place over a period of 10 years. it will be recalled that during that time there had been a number of incumbents of both of those high offices of the State. All of them have been denied access to the detailed information which has now been provided to me, and which has identified the situation described in this Report.

That is the only defence which has been put forward by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and other speakers in regard to this situation. But if honourable members look at the preceding paragraph and read that sensibly they can see that that demolishes the argument which the Government seeks to found upon paragraph 3.10. What did the Commissioner say? He said:

I am subject to a duty to investigate into matters such as these and to report upon them. I cannot properly discharge that duty without setting out in detail the facts upon which my conclusions are based. Yet I am restricted by the operation of Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act so as to set out those facts in such a manner that no person can reasonably identify the taxpayer concerned. Accordingly, although I set out the facts in detail, together with dates and places, I have refrained from identifying the taxpayer or the tax promoter.

There is the answer to the Government's question. The Commissioner says that the operation of section 16 is confining and restricting him in the same way, presumably, as section 16 operated in May 1978 when the Commissioner of Taxation , it is said, first acquainted the Treasurer with details of about these things. Section 16 was operating then. It is operating now in respect of the Royal Commissioner. Section 16 is concerned with any significant details about the individual concerned. But there is no way in the world in which in 1978 the existence of section 16 prevented the dimensions of what was occurring being brought to the attention of the Treasurer. There is no way that the operation of section 16 has prevented the Royal Commissioner setting out the dimensions of the loss of revenue to this day. I remind the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the honourable member for North Sydney that he did that in his third interim report before section 16 has been subsequently amended. In other words, the fact that section 16, directed towards stopping the provision of details in respect of an individual, existed did not preclude the Treasurer himself being approached on this matter at least as early as may 1978. It did not in its unamended form prevent the Royal Commissioner exposing last year and before the dimensions of what was happening.

There is no way in which any intelligent person can say that when the Attorney- General and the Treasurer were approached, as they were, with suggestions as to the dimensions of the problem existing they were not in a position to form a judgment that investigations had been taking place which showed the dimension of the problem and that they were not informed of the inquiries that were taking place within the Attorney-General's Department and the Solicitor-General's Department. One must come to one of two conclusions-either they were told about the inquiries that originated back in 1973-74 and the recommendations that had been made by Brinsden and the other Queen's Counsel or, if they were not informed, they were so grossly incompetent that their resignations should be required on the basis of incompetence. One has to have it one way or the other.

One cannot imagine in terms of the report that the Ministers responsible did not have the competence to be alerted by what was said to them at least as early as May 1978. Either they were told or, if they were not told, they failed in terms of the competence one requires of Ministers dealing with a situation which is not peripheral. Has $1m or $2m been lost? At least $10m has been lost to Commonwealth revenue. And the Government wants to say to this House and the people of Australia: 'Well, I am sorry'. This has been going on. The Treasurer concedes that the matter was raised in May 1978. But the Government wants this House and this country to say, 'Well, that is something that we will cop because they did not know and if they did not know there is no question of their competence being an issue'.

The question is also raised of whether, in fact, there was some way in which the Australian Labor Party could be criticised because nothing was done in the period when it was in office. Let us refer to the report on this matter. We can dispose of this question very quickly. It arises under the heading on page 33 of the report 'The Lamentable History of Non-Prosecution'. The only point in the Royal Commissioner's report at which there is reference to action being taken is in the period when the Labor Government was in office. Page 36 of the report refers to the second opinion of Mr Brinsden, Q.C. He had already given one opinion in 1974 and he was asked for another. Honourable members should remember what this Queen's Counsel had said. I read from paragraph 3.27:
He delivered his opinion between Christmas and the New Year.
This was at the end of 1974. The paragraph continues:

His firm advice was that the promoter and two others should be charged with a breach of Section 86 (e) of the Crimes Act, and that they should be subjected to certain civil proceedings which I will describe later.
Paragraph 3.29 refers to the second opinion which Mr Brinsden gave in June 1975. It states:

He expressed the view that Section 16 of the Income Tax Act constituted no hindrance to the prosecution. His opinion was transmitted to Canberra to the Commissioner of Taxation a month later. Three weeks later the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth was instructed: '. . . it has been decided that action under section 86 of the Crimes Act . . . should be commenced against (the three men) as soon as possible'.
Action was in fact initiated and authorisation given in the period when the Labor Government was in office, because in the next few words the Commissioner said:
It was August 1975.

In other words, in the whole of this report the only time when action has been indicated by the Royal Commissioner as having been taken and authorised was in the period of the labor Government. It is the period since to which the words: ' The Lamentable History of Non-Prosecution' are applied.

We have the opinion from Brinsden, Q.C. He went on to become a supreme court judge. As my Deputy Leader and Leader have indicated, we have the opinions from senior counsel. The only things against those opinions in this whole process were clearly the opinions and obfusction of people whose integrity-I will not name them; they have already been named-has been brought absolutely into question, the officers in Perth who made sure that the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were not brought to justice by adopting a bottom-of-the-drawer approach. Knowledge of those schemes was put away in the bottom of the drawer. At no point has there been any attempt on the part of the Treasurer, the Attorney-General or the Prime Minister in his speech here today to justify any competent Minister, who within his department had unqualified advice from senior counsel whose competence could not be called into question and against which advice the only thing that existed was some obfuscation from a junior, a public servant in the office in Perth, not accepting the principles of the Westminster system.

Let us as we come to the later stages of this debate ask ourselves what they are. Are the principles of the Westminster system those which were referred to in 1972 by the gentleman who is now the Prime Minister. He said then that if there is any blunder in the department concerned the system requires that the Minister should accept the responsibility and tender his resignation. Did he mean that then or did he not? Does the Government now say that it is appropriate for a party to have one set of principles when it is in Opposition but not to apply them when it is in Government? Quite clearly, in 1972 Mr Fraser held the view that if there was a blunder in a department the Minister should tender his resignation. Is it a question of definition? Do we have to spend much time suggesting that the loss of $10 billion-the acquisition of which could have eliminated poverty in this country-and the refusal to collect it when there was advice from senior counsel to do so was not a blunder? Does that not qualify as the type of situation which the Prime Minister said demanded the offering of the resignation of the Minister in question? Have we not the situation the Prime Minister talked about in July of 1975 when he said that the skipping over of the full facts are a misleading of the Parliament? It simply is not good enough for the Treasurer to say in this House 'Yes, I did know from May of 1978; I did get some indication that there was a case for prosecution' and to come up with the lame excuse that the reason something was not done was that there was a view amongst some members of the Government to the effect that new legislation was not needed to remedy the situation. By any view what has come out in the fourth interim report of the Costigan Royal Commission, which was set up to chase the unions but which has now brought the Government to a situation where it should resign, is that both the Ministers in question should tender their resignations and the Government should resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the words of the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) there is no indication whatsoever in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and on certain tax matters that there is any implication for any Minister of the Crown. By linking Mr Costigan with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and saying that they are of equal standing, have the same competence, the same powers and the same access to information, he has completely misrepresented the powers of the Royal Commissioner. Members of the House and all associated with this matter see that that is a completely fallacious argument. SPEECH.PARA: Let us extend the argument advanced by the honourable member for Wills and seek to establish in our own minds whether it would be proper for the Treasurer to have detailed and precise information on the tax matters of any individual. I can imagine a Treasurer, without the ethics or commitment to the task that the present Treasurer has, vilifying and abusing individuals sitting in the chamber, using information that had been provided under the circumstances that the honourable member for Wills proposes, under the circumstances that the honourable member for Wills maintains apply at this moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not proposed anything.

—The honourable member for Wills should not misrepresent his own argument. He has misrepresented the case of Costigan and the Treasurer, the Honourable John Howard. It seems to me that no person in this place seriously advances the argument that a Treasurer or an Attorney-General should know the details of cases that are before the Crown or facts about the income of and income tax paid by individuals. Is that the argument that the honourable member for Wills is advancing? It seems to me that he argued, on the one hand, that there should be some discrete relationship between the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer and, on the other hand, that there has been knowledge, that there must be knowledge and that knowledge is desirable. That is not factual. He knows it is not factual. His arguments are fallacious. Neither the Treasurer nor the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has been connected by this report in any way with the actions of their departments and the officers who are responsible for them. Certainly there has been a massive case of negligence, a sorry story of misapplication; and perhaps some criminal or untoward activity is hinted at in Western Australia. These matters have to be investigated. They must be nailed, and the individuals who are or were public servants must be brought to book.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us assess this matter and examine exactly where it began. The lamentable story began in early 1973, as the Royal Commissioner said. By mid-1974 the investigation officer, Mr Todman, decided that he would seek legal advice. He sought that legal advice. Not only did he advise the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia, the head of the Taxation Office there, but also he advised the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Western Australia. That was in September 1974. However, having advised those people during the term of the Labor Government, having advised the senior officers of the two departments involved of his concern, further information was sought and Mr Brinsden was required to prepare an opinion for the Deputy Crown Solicitor. This he did over Christmas 1974. But in May and June he was required to give further information. The report of the Royal Commissioner states:

A request was made for further opinion from counsel on that matter, to which he immediately attended and delivered his opinion on 25 June 1975, within three weeks of the brief being delivered . . . Three weeks later the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth was instructed: . . . 'it has been decided that action under section 86 of the Crimes Act . . . should be commenced against (the three men)' . . .

That was in June 1975. Later on, however, if we become aware of matters that were proceeding at the same time, it became obvious that not only were the officials in Perth advised of these matters but also the Commissioner of Taxation and the Crown Solicitor in Canberra were made aware of them. In mid- 1975, six months before the fall of the Labor Government, these facts were known in Canberra by the utmost senior officials of those departments. No action followed. Nothing was done by those officials.

Let us examine who the Ministers of the day were. I will tell the House who the Ministers responsible for this incompetence were. In 1973 when this matter first became known the Treasurer was Frank Crean. Later it was James Ford Cairns. Later again in 1975 it was William George Hayden. In fact for six months the senior officers of the Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department knew about these matters. Nothing was done. Why was nothing done? Why were those Treasurers not advised? I use against the honourable member for Wills the same arguments that he used against the current Treasurer. The simple fact is that they were not advised because they are not entitled to be advised. The provisions of the Act under which the Crown Solicitor works are such that they are not advised. Why was Hayden not advised?

I turn now to the Attorney-General of the day. When this matter began Lionel Keith Murphy was Attorney-General. He was not advised. Why did he not take action? The second Attorney-General was Keppel Earl Enderby, Q.C. I am advised that Mr Enderby, when he was Attorney-General or Minister for Industry and Commerce, made the enlightening statement that exports come from abroad! What a delightful statement! There is no responsibility on these men that I have named nor is there any responsibility on the Treasurer or the Attorney-General. There is not responsibility on them; and Costigan says there is not. He hints not one bit at it nor does he indicate that there is a responsibility for a Minister.

This motion of censure is a fallacious motion. What has happened during this period? I consider that the Royal Commissioner, during the period of his investigation, dealt not only with tax matters but also with matters from which the Australian Labor Party seeks to divert us. He dealt with matters of great importance for the behaviour of senior officials within one of the union movements in Australia. They are matters with which I consider the Labor Party does not want to deal. They concern the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. This motion is a smokescreen by the Australian Labor Party to divert attention from one of those bodies which are affiliated with it, and which contributes to its funds.

I have extracted, in a fairly concise way and to the best of my ability, information from the balance sheets of various unions and have tried to assign their affiliation funds and political funds, as the unions prescribe and allocate them to the Australian Labor Party. Let us take the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. it is interesting to note that in 1979 it paid out to the Australian Labor Party a mere $77 000 in one fund and $192 000 in another fund. The following year it made payments of $116 000 and $224 000. I can provide similiar figures for the Builders Labourers Federation, the Transport Workers Union of Australia and the Federated Storeman and Packers Union of Australia. How much has the Labor Party collected from the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? How much has the Labor Party been able to benefit from the activities of this group of thugs and criminals who are responsible for killings, robbery, the circumstances of the Station Hotel and all those other matters enunciated by Mr Costigan? What has the Labor Party done to rid itself of these people? What has the union movement done to rid itself of these people? Is there any rule within the Australian Labor Party that no one with a criminal record can be associated with it? There is not. Is there a rule within any union movement in Australia that people with criminal records cannot hold office? There is not. If there is not, why is there not?

Today we are debating the proposition that by some sheer shred of chance a Treasurer or an Attorney-General may have known of certain facts. I have demonstrated that, if they knew of such facts, previous Attorneys-General and previous Treasurers must have known of the same facts. Yet the Australian Labor Party continues to associate and to identify itself with people such as members of the Federated Ship and Painters and Dockers Union. I refer to the basis of the association of the Australian Labor Party with the union movement and the way in which it may be modified by changes that have been made to the platform of the Australian Labor Party. Those changes seek to move unions outside and above the law. The Australian Labor Party wishes to deal with unions as if they have only the rights set out within the Conciliation and Arbitration Act with no civil responsibilities placed on them. The Platform Constitution and Rules of the Australian Labor Party booklet states:

A Labor Government will recognise the right of workers to bargain collectively (which) 'entails the right to take industrial action without pains and penalties being directed against unions for the exercise of that right'.
A Labor Government is committed to the following objectives:
. . . The recognition of rights of unions to regulate their own affairs in a democratic way free from Government and judicial interference.

There are other changes to the platform of the Australian Labor Party. A Labor Government would: Exempt unions from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act; encourage the membership of registered organisations through the provision of preference for unionists; and recognise that the legitimate role of the trade unions is not limited to legally defined industrial matters. The Platform Constitution and Rules booklet states:
All contracts made by the Australian Government would be required to provide for preference to unionists.

Other matters are dealt with in the report but the final one which I wish to identify is the repeal of penalties for industrial action against arbitral decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and a prohibition on the insertion of bans clauses. That, in toto, comes from the party which today is talking about matters contained in the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such a lofty moral tone, too.

—Indeed, I wonder just where the morality of this motion is. First of all the ALP accepts payments from an organisation that can best be described as criminal-criminal in intent, criminal in activity and criminal in every aspect of its operations. It takes funds from that union and from other unions the individual members of which are before courts on similar matters. The Australian Labor Party, taking funds from criminals who, as reported by the Royal Commissioner, have involved themselves in murder, robbery, extortion and many other criminal actions, has now prepared a platform which says: 'Not only will we support and give regard to the union movement in Australia but also we will give unions preference so that the normal provisions of common law will not apply to them'. The Labor Party would move the unions beyond the realms of normal law. It has proposed within its platform to deal with unions in a manner different from the manner in which they would deal with ordinary citizens of Australia. In those circumstances the Australian Labor Party commits itself not only to take funds from but also to supply support to and to give a free reign to the activities of criminals.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard the motion before the House as an incredibly poor one if the Opposition wishes to distract attention from the other matters dealt with in the Costigan report. They are dealt with in the report and those sections of the report will be read and understood by the Australian community. The Australian community will not identify this report with a Treasurer or an Attorney-General. If that were the case, it would have to identify this report with a number of office holders, a number of Treasurers and a number of Attorneys-General. It will not do that because it understands that there is no way that Mr William George Hayden knew in 1975 that certain matters were going on in Western Australia or in other places. It would not connect the activities of Mr Keppel Enderby as Attorney-General with the affairs of Western Australia. The Australian community will not connect the activities of Mr John Howard with the affairs in Perth, nor will it connect the activities of the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, with the affairs in Western Australia. If the public did it for one, it would do it for the lot. That is what I say.

The proposition that I put to the House is that the Australian Labor Party, by its close association with the union movement and by its commitment to and control from, the union movement, is committed to drawing a smokescreen across the most serious matters dealt with in this report. I venture to suggest that the Victorian Government will do the same thing. The Victorian Government will seek to run from the implications of this report. To ensure that the House understands what the Royal Commissioner said and what the Government has done, I quote from the report:

I have taken evidence from the Taxation Office as to the magnitude of the problem. Until the mid-1970s the Taxation Office had not been confronted with large scale fraud practised upon the revenue, or if it had, it had not been aware of it. It became aware of it in the mid-1970s. It then set about establishing an office in Canberra to monitor the matter and make a response to it. There were great difficulties in detecting the particular frauds. Information came to the Officer after the frauds had been committed, the promoters were secretive, documents were destroyed, company records were not filed with Corporate Affairs Office. False names and false addresses of common criminals skilled in the hiding of information were used. Nonetheless the Office took steps and made efforts.
Despite those difficulties, the Taxation Office pursued the matter. In regard to the need for a task force, a task force which the Government has established, Mr Costigan states:

My final recommendation is that a Task Force be formed consisting of counsel, solicitors, investigators and administrative staff to act on behalf of the Commonwealth and the several states in the criminal and civil actions available to punish those who have perpetrated the fraud, and to recover the revenue lost.

That has been done. The prosecutor has been appointed and announced and the task force has been formed. Immediately on the receipt of this report action has followed. The proposition brought forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) is fallacious. It is not credible and in fact shows the wish to distract from the real contents of the Royal Commission's report.
