SPEECH.PARA: Let me draw attention to the context of this debate because it has been going on for a while. We are debating a motion of censure of the Government for its grave failure in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against the tax laws, resulting in multi-billion dollar frauds against the Commonwealth. This is brought before the House in the context of a report which exposes, once again, an enormous tax avoidance fraud that is going on in this country. This is, of course, not the first time that we have had evidence of tax avoidance and evasion. This Government has presided over the most alarming and incredible explosion of tax avoidance and evasion to occur in the history of this nation. That is the full context in which this debate has come before the House. In that period we have seen an unparalleled explosion in tax cheating in this country.

Some things have been done about tax avoidance, but virtually nothing has been done about tax evasion. In the last report of the Commissioner of Taxation there is recognition that the number of identified tax avoiders was 26 times higher than that for the last year of the Labor Government. The Government has brought in various pieces of legislation against tax avoidance. In fact, since 1978 it has brought in 22 pieces of such legislation covering over 50 avoidance schemes. The Taxation Office has uncovered about 100 tax avoidance schemes whilst this Government has been in office and only 50 have been legislated against. All this has involved closing the door after the tax avoider has bolted because all of it has applied from the date on which the pronouncements were made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). In only one case-the Curran case-was any restrospectivity involved, and then it was only slight. That a tax avoidance explosion has occurred under this Government is undoubted. The legislative attempts by this Government to prevent it have been basically futile. Professor Mathews of the Australian National University has estimated that the tax avoidance loss is in the order of $3,000m a year.

I have mentioned the Curran scheme. The Treasurer said today in his contribution to this debate that the Labor Party had failed to close off the Curran scheme. It is certainly true that in December 1974 the then Treasurer, Frank Crean, announced an intention by the Government to legislate against it but did not do so in 1975. We accept that. The year 1975 was a pretty torrid year for the Labor Party. But in 1976, 1977 and until the middle of 1978 the Liberals did nothing either. So if we are to be condemned for not doing anything in one year-a year when our Government was under great strain through the actions of the then Opposition-how about the next two years in which no such strain existed? This Government did absolutely nothing for two and a half years. During that time that scheme got under way and all the massive losses occurred in those years, not in the last year of office of the Labor Government. Let us get it straight: The delays in respect of the Curran scheme are much more attributable to the present Government than they are to the Labor Government.

As regards tax evasion, which is what this debate is basically about, we have had estimates about the extent of the tax loss through tax evasion at present. Both the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd have estimated that the cash economy in this country is now running at about 10 per cent of the total recorded economy. That indicates a tax loss of about $3,000m a year through the cash economy. The Government has done virtually nothing about that. What has it done? It announced in 1978 an intention to legislate against the cash economy in the building industry but, after a few screams, it backed off and abandoned that legislation. Subsequently we have had only one other piece of legislation; namely, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. It was introduced at the end of 1980 when, most belatedly, the Treasurer finally got round to doing something about closing off the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. This scheme, as we now know, has been running since 1973. It took us only seven years to close off that scheme!

A lot of this debate is about how culpable the Government is in waiting so long to take any action at all. I believe it is important to make the point here that there are only two examples of this Government taking any action against tax evasion. In the first instance it announced its intention and backed off and in the other it introduced legislation in December 1980, but most belatedly. Since then we have had an announcement of an intention to do something else but we have not yet seen that legislation. I guess we will soon see the legislation if the Government does not cave in to the pressures which are being placed upon it.

There is one other point I would like to make on tax evasion: that is, that the Government in this Budget is saying that it will take some action against tax evasion. At the same time it is promoting the cash economy. It is a remarkable irony that in the one Budget the Government is doing those two things. The action against the cash economy has to be offset against the fact that it is introducing a tax on banking transactions. There is no doubt whatever that a tax on banking transactions will be a great encouragement to the cash economy. It will encourage people not to do their transactions through the banks because that would incur a tax. So there is now a dramatic tax incentive for people to undertake their activities outside the banking system. That most certainly will be a great encouragement to the cash economy and to tax evasion in this country. The Government's supposed concern about this matter as expressed in the Budget is undone by another action undertaken in this same Budget.

While I am on this point about the past actions of this Government, I mention quickly the foreign tax credit scheme which was mentioned earlier in this debate . The Treasurer mentioned in his speech that he had decided not to go ahead with that legislation because it would have been damaging to the Australian economy. When he was introducing that legislation in this House he had this to say as recorded in the Hansard of June 1978:
The fact that major elements of the foreign source income of Australians are not taxable in Australia seriously prejudices the equity of the tax system.

That is what he said when he introduced the legislation, but he soon forgot about the serious prejudice of the equity of the tax system when the pressures came on him and he decided that it was not in the interests of the Australian economy. But all this is minor compared to what has now come to light; a history of gross failure to act on the most amazing and widespread tax-cheating scheme of them all-the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. The full ramifications of this scheme and the Government's grossly inadequate response to it would never have come to light if it were not for two reports. Of course those reports are the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

The Treasurer claimed in this debate that these reports were both commissioned by Liberal governments. That is true. The McCabe-Lafranchi report was commissioned by the Victorian Liberal Government and the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union report was commissioned by the Victorian Liberal Government and the present Federal Government. It is relevant also to bear in mind that the previous Liberal Thompson Government sat on the McCabe-Lafranchi report for six months. It clearly had no intention of making that report public. It got the damn thing at the end of last year. When the Labor Government came to power in May of this year it made that report public. If a Labor Government had not been elected we still would not know about the findings of McCabe-Lafranchi and we still would not know about the details of the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme as it occurred in the Victorian context. I presume that we would have known something about that by now from Mr Costigan. We certainly would not have known the enormous ramifications of it that we now know through the McCabe-Lafranchi report. The previous Liberal Government in Victoria quite clearly was sitting on that report, hiding the ramifications of tax evasion in order to protect its friends. No other conclusion can be drawn.

In regard to the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union the last thing that either this Government or the Thompson Government expected when they set up that Royal Commission was that these kinds of findings would come to light. They thought they were setting up something to nail the Australian Labor Party. But of course that is not what has happened. They are now hoist on their own petard. These reports have revealed that the Government has dragged the anchor appallingly in regard to taking any action against the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The evidence of delay and neglect is overwhelming. Given the issues at stake the Government deserves the declaration by this House of no confidence. Particularly is this so given that when action was finally very belatedly taken in December 1980 by the passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act to close off this scheme, the Government made no attempt to collect the tax that had been evaded up to that time.

We have a situation where legislation was brought in, as I mentioned, in December 1980 to close off the scheme. The Government knew that the scheme had been going on for years and years. It must have known by then of the enormous ramifications of this scheme but it made not one skerrick of an attempt then to collect all of the revenue which had been lost through that scheme up until that point of time. We believe that the Government is utterly culpable for that. It has taken some action in that regard now but only because the McCabe-Lafranchi report came out and forced it into that action. Had there been no McCabe- Lafranchi report the Treasurer of this nation would not have announced the subsequent legislation in an attempt to get that revenue back-revenue which he now calculates as running at something in the order of $450m. The Government brought in that legislation in December 1980 knowing that that revenue loss was at stake. It did not do a damn thing about trying to ensure that it was got back for the public revenue. We believe that that alone justifies the terms of the censure motion which has been moved before this House.

The Treasurer said in his defence that the secrecy provisions exempt him from blame; that the use of existing criminal and civil law may not have worked; and that when this scheme first came to light public attitudes about tax avoidance were not strong. I will just briefly deal with these three points of defence which the Treasurer has thrown up in debate today. We believe it is nonsense to say that the secrecy provisions preclude him from knowing what is going on. They prevent disclosure of names or specific details of schemes but they do not prevent the Treasurer from being informed of the general details of the schemes and of their extremely serious nature. Of course the evidence is that he was so informed. Indeed he admitted it in debate here today. In the comments that he made on the McCabe-Lafranchi report in June of this year he said:

When the Commissioner of Taxation first raised with me in May 1978 the prospect that criminal penalties might need to be introduced in order to deal with these practices, they were still being documented and the full extent of their use was not yet know.

So he admitted then that the Commissioner of Taxation told him in mid-1978 about these schemes. He did not know exactly how far they had gone but he knew that they were there, that they were serious, and that he may well have had to contemplate criminal penalties. He knew at least at that time. One presumes that he was also told then about all of the other inquiries that had been going on, about using the existing law and about all of the opinions that were around. I have referred to this in the debate. I said earlier that one could proceed with prosecutions under existing law. But even if he were in some doubt about that he still did absolutely nothing for 2 1/2 years except to cogitate on whether he could use existing law.

We believe that the Government, and the Treasurer in particular, are thoroughly culpable for that kind of action. To say that the secrecy provisions are in some way a defence is an utter absurdity. The Treasurer knew about the scheme. He knew it was serious. He did nothing for 2 1/2 years. Of course he may even have known before May 1978. Accepting that that is the first point at which he became aware then at least the 2 1/2 years delay is undeniable. Of course he had a duty to demand that everything possible be done to close off this scheme. If he did not do so-he did not-then clearly he was negligent. If he were being led up the garden path regarding the use of existing criminal and civil law to tackle these schemes he should have brought in this legislation well before December 1980. He should have made it retrospective. Of course he did none of that. He did nothing for 2 1/2 years. The reason he gave for this in his statement on the McCabe- Lafranchi report was:
. . . strong public attitudes towards tax avoidance were not yet evident at that time.

What a pathetic and lousy excuse to say: 'We knew that this scheme was serious. There was a big tax loss. We were not quite sure what to do about it. We decided to do nothing really because strong public attitudes towards avoidance were not evident at that time'. In other words, the Government would do nothing unless it was forced into it. It is being forced into it by two reports-the McCabe- Lafranchi report, which a Liberal Government tried to hide, and the Costigan report, which neither Government can hide. That is what has forced the Government into taking the action which it has taken. If it had been left to the Government then it would have done nothing except to take the action which was taken in December 1980 when the loss of revenue through that scheme became so hot that it knew that it had to stop it at some point. But it would have done nothing more than that if it had not been forced to do so by the publication of those reports. The Government would have relied on the fact that the public would not have been incensed about it because they would not have known about it . When the public became incensed, as they rightly were by the McCabe-Lafranchi report, then the Government decided that it had to do something more. That is when it announced the retrospective legislation to ensure that it got back that revenue. That is what has led to further action in respect of the recommendations of the Costigan report.

The Treasurer argued that the use of the existing criminal or civil law may not have been successful. What a lousy argument that is. That is a nonsense argument . He should have gone ahead and used it whether or not he was sure it would work . He should have gone ahead and used the criminal and civil law that was there when he had opinions available to him saying that he could use that law. Then in order to be doubly sure-because he could not be absolutely sure, as he rightly said, that that would work-he should have brought in legislation against it in 1978 when he knew about the scheme. He should have used both tacks in 1978, not December 1980. He should have used the existing law which Commissioner Costigan says was quite clearly usable and, secondly, if he was unsure about whether it would work, brought in legislation to ensure that he had the point covered anyway. That is what he should have done. He did neither of those things. He forgot about it for 2 1/2 years.

Finally, there is the matter of the responsibility of Ministers under the Westminster system whether they knew or not. In our view they and the Government as a whole knew enough to be held thoroughly responsible for the delays in this regard. Even if they did not know, under the Westminster system they have an obligation to resign if actions in their department are such that a scandal is created and someone should take the blame. They should be men enough to stand up and say: 'We should have known about this. We should take the blame'. That is the Westminster system, and they should live by it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate at a very late stage to defend the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) because I represent him in this House. It is my responsibility to defend him-
—If you do not defend him really well you will get the job.

—I can assure the honourable member that I will still try very hard indeed to defend him. All the evidence is there on which it is easy to defend him. I believe he could present an unanswerable case indeed if he were here. Not only do I defend the Attorney-General cheerfully and willingly but also I defend him on the basis of the facts as we know them and on the basis of the arguments that have been put by both sides in this debate. The first thing that should be made perfectly clear in defence of the Attorney-General is that, leaving aside all the matters that we are concerned with in this debate, the Attorney-General has been and still is a good Attorney-General and has made very substantial contributions to the reform of the law in this country. That should not be forgotten or overlooked. The Attorney-General has been responsible for law reform of a very substantial measure. Let us understand that and accept it as a fair and reasonable basis from which to start.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the issue that arises in this debate so far as the Attorney-General is concerned is whether he is guilty of any impropriety by virtue of his knowledge of or involvement in the matters that have been canvassed in this debate. The answer that one must come to, looking at the whole of the evidence and listening to all the arguments, is that the Attorney-General has nothing to answer for whatsoever. No ground whatsoever has been made out as to why he should resign or as to why it could be said that he is guilty of any impropriety in this matter. It is said, as I apprehend the arguments of the Australian Labor Party, that the Attorney-General had some knowledge of the matters which have quite rightly been criticised by Mr Costigan in his report. If he had knowledge of these matters, he must have had that knowledge directly, indirectly or on some other presumed basis. In other words, it is said that he either knew what was going on-in which case he should resign or stands condemned-or it can be assumed that he had some sort of implied knowledge.

Let us look at those propositions briefly. There is no evidence whatsoever-not a scintilla or a syllable of evidence-to suggest that the Attorney-General knew personally or directly of any of the matters deserving of reproof or criticism which have come to light in this matter. Let me give an example of direct knowledge so far as a Minister is concerned. I refer to an old case relating to the very field we are concerned with; namely, taxation. This case has been mentioned before in this debate and it concerns a former Treasurer, Mr Crean. This matter became popularly known as Curran's case. It was in fact, not to put too fine a point on it, a tax avoidance scheme, and it became famous.

The former Treasurer, Mr Crean, had direct knowledge of that matter. That can be easily established because he made at least one public statement which I recall reading in which he indicated perfectly clearly that he was aware of it. He knew the tax avoidance scheme existed and was being practised. He knew his colleagues in the Ministry at that time likewise knew about it. He made personal statements about it and had direct knowledge of it. His colleagues, from the Prime Minister to the most humble Minister in his Government at that time, must be fixed with direct and personal knowledge of that tax avoidance scheme. What was the response? The Government took no action whatsoever, despite the fact that it had direct and personal knowledge of that tax avoidance scheme. I mention that case because it is an example of direct knowledge on the part of a Minister. Let me repeat the point very briefly: There is no evidence whatsoever- not a syllable of evidence-to suggest that the Attorney-General knew personally or had direct knowledge by any other means of any of those matters that stand condemned and which have been criticised in the Costigan report or raised in the debate here today.

If that is the case it can be said against the Attorney-General by way of criticism only that he had some sort of implied knowledge, that we can presume that he had some sort of knowledge-not direct but indirect. There again the case against him fails. Indeed, not only does the case against him fail but also I will establish very shortly that the Attorney-General is one of the very few people involved in this matter who in fact took positive action. I will refer to that matter in a moment. But is it said-I apprehend that it is said by the Labor Party-that the Attorney-General can be presumed to have known of the unseemly matters that have been the subject of criticism in the Costigan report? The important thing to understand is that the Attorney-General, the Treasurer and indeed any Minister labours in these circumstances under a very severe restriction, and that is the restriction contained in section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the provision known as the secrecy provision.

The Opposition has said-I suppose it is entitled to raise the argument-that this is no defence and that it is no excuse to say that a secrecy provision in the Income Tax Assessment Act prevents Ministers having personal knowledge of these matters. I say to the Opposition that it explains very substantially indeed the limitations that any Minister labours under. I will not read again the two extracts from the Costigan report in which the Royal Commissioner makes the point that a Minister labours under a very severe disadvantage because of the secrecy provisions. I will not take the time of the House by repeating those passages. Let me simply record for the record that they are paragraphs 3.10 and 3.132. I hope that every fair-minded person who wants to make a judgment about the Attorney-General will read what Mr Costigan stated.

Let me go on to say, in reply to members of the Opposition who say in effect that this is no defence and no excuse, that the secrecy provision relates to the taxation affairs of a person. What were being investigated and what were being handled in a very leisurely and slack manner in the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth were the taxation affairs of a person-one company. It would have been completely wrong and completely contrary to the law for public servants to run to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) or to the Attorney-General saying: 'Let us tell you about the scandalous state of affairs we have discovered concerning the taxation affairs of a person who happens to be a company'. That would be contrary to the law of this Commonwealth, contrary to the well established practice and contrary , I hope, to what every citizen would expect to be the case. Taxation affairs above all are a matter between the citizen and the independent Commissioner of Taxation. They are not and should not be matters of political investigation and political pursuit. I set that context very clearly. It is important and it does make it perfectly plain that there is a very severe limitation on the knowledge which comes to a Minister, the Attorney-General or the Treasurer in any taxation matter. Also this is highlighted by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I make the further point that the Government is giving an undertaking that it will look with the utmost speed to see whether it is necessary to amend that provision of the income tax legislation.

Let me say that the Attorney-General-this is the substantial defence that I want to put on his behalf-is one of the very few people involved in this matter who has taken personal, positive, direct and prompt action. Quite apart from the question of whether he has a good defence, in fact he is in a very strong position because he took the initiative himself before this matter became a matter of public notoriety.

Let me tell honourable members when the Attorney-General first took action in this matter. I make it plain, beyond any doubt, that it was before the Costigan report was presented to the Government. It was before the two witnesses-O' Sullivan and Bercove-gave evidence before the Costigan Royal Commission. The Attorney-General was not slack; he was not slow or off the mark. He took positive action even before people gave evidence before the Costigan Royal Commission, that is, even before the facts which are now a matter of notoriety became known. I hope that if any Opposition speakers follow me in this debate they will at least give the Attorney-General credit for that. He took action. For the record, I point out that the Attorney-General became aware of the case in the Perth office after the McCabe-Lafranchi report from Victoria was published on 27 May. What did the Attorney-General do then, remembering that this was before Bercove and O'Sullivan had given evidence, before Mr Costigan had made his criticisms and before Mr Costigan had given his report to us? Did he sit and do nothing? Of course not! He took positive and prompt action, and he did so immediately.

At the beginning of June the Attorney-General sought advice from the Solicitor- General about the opinion which had been given concerning the bottom-of-the- harbour case in Perth. He took action even before Mr Costigan knew of the unseemly matters that are now the subject of debate in this House. Frankly I think the Attorney-General has a very good defence. For the record I will read a statement into Hansard and then I will conclude my remarks. The Attorney-General is entitled to have this in Hansard and he is entitled to have it on the public record in his defence. First of all, I give credit to the journalist who asked what was, so far as I am concerned, the only relevant question in the whole debate, from beginning to end. The journalist, who asked the question yesterday at Senator Durack's Press conference, stated:
Senator, when was the first time you became aware of Mr Brinsden's recommendation to proceed with the prosecution . . .

In other words the journalist asked the Attorney-General: 'When did you first know about all this unseemly business?: It is set out in the record. I will not take the time to read it all out but I will read part of what the Attorney- General said in reply. He said:

We first became aware-you've put two questions there-the first question is when did I become aware of the fact that there was an opinion given to the Perth office on the facts as given-and of course you have to bear in mind that facts have got to be proved. But on those facts if they were proved that that would amount to a conspiracy to defraud, and there was law available for that, I first became aware--
This is the important part-
of that after the McCabe-Lafranchi Report was tabled and it was then that the Treasurer and I decided that we should obtain the opinion of the Solicitor- General on those facts.

Long before Mr Costigan had probably even heard of Mr Bercove or O'Sullivan, before they had given evidence, before Costigan knew of the unseemly matters that he has now dug up and before the report had come to the Government, the Attorney-General used his initiative to pursue those matters and to get that opinion from the Solicitor-General. Not only does the Attorney-General have a very good defence but also he comes out of this whole matter with very great credit indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention firstly to what we are debating, and that is the censure of the Government for its failure in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against the tax laws. Before dealing with the matter in detail I want to refer briefly to what the Minister for Communications (Mr N.A. Brown) said in defence of the Attorney- General (Senator Durack). He indicated that the Attorney-General became aware of certain matters after the McCabe-Lafranchi report. He sought advice on them and took action immediately. The main matter that we are talking about today is the failure of this Government, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer before him, the present Attorney-General and Attorneys-General before him to take any action in relation to cases which have now been referred to as bottom-of-the- harbour cases or the stripping of companies which first became known to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation early in 1973. We are talking about a long while ago. I will refer later to a statement, historically on that, by the present Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard nothing today, other than excuses, about why no real action has been taken against the practices referred to in the McCabe-Lafranchi report, particularly prior to the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980. The Treasurer repeatedly uses the excuse-he did it again today-that there was no way that action could have been taken prior to that legislation in 1980. That is just not true and has no basis from a legal point of view. Purely for political motives the attitude adopted by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, and his predecessor, Sir Phillip Lynch has been that it was convenient for this Government to adopt that view, thereby allowing white collar criminals to defraud the Commonwealth of revenue. That practice has now become the hallmark of this Government. It has gone on for years and years, and we have heard nothing but excuses from both the Treasurer and his predecessor about why action was not taken.

What was the true position? Legal opinions were in the possession of the Treasurer which showed clearly that prosecutions could have been undertaken before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980. The facts are that there was an opinion given to the Government by a Melbourne Q.C. in 1978. That opinion was dealt with in some detail by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the debate today. In effect, that opinion advised the Government that if a conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth were established there would be a strong possibility that the agreement, the subject of that conspiracy, would be, in fact, a nullity ; that is, there would be no transfer of shares at all. The opinion stated:
In that situation and from a practical view-point the Commissioner would probably look to the vendor to recover the lost income tax.

That was in 1978. What happened? Absolutely nothing happened. This Government took no action at all against people who were defrauding the Commonwealth of massive amounts of money. By November 1980 the Treasurer had two more opinions, one from Mr N. M. Forsyth which spelt out that calculated and fraudulent tax evasion was already a grave criminal offence. The opinion cited section 231 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, section 86 (1) of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and section 124 (1) and (3) of the Companies Act. These were only examples. The opinion stated also that other sections of the Companies Act, Bankruptcy Act and State crimes Acts and common law offences could have been used against calculated and fraudulent evasion of tax. The opinion further stated:
How it can be said that they-
Referring to the sections-
are inadequate when they have not even been tested in such a situation, I find rather surprising.

That is the crucial point. The Treasurer and the Attorney-General and people representing the Attorney-General, the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen)- whoever it may be-can all go on about the fact that they needed the legislation in 1980 before they could do anything. But the fact of the matter is that they did not try to do anything. That was the point made in that opinion given to the Treasurer as early as November 1980.

The second opinion that he received was in 1980 where, in fact, Mr Forsyth, Q.C ., said that very thing when referring to the sections: How they could be said to be inadequate when they have not even been tested in such a situation is rather surprising. That view was further supported in a joint opinion again given to the Treasurer by Mr G. L. Davies, Q.C., and Mr D. G. Russell. At that stage the Treasurer had in his possession three opinions that we know about which said that people could be prosecuted for conspiracy and for offences under the Crimes Act. How many other opinions he had we do not know. We know that he had at least three. That was the position when, on 26 November 1980, the Treasurer introduced into this House the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill. Despite legal opinions in the possession of the Treasurer no action had been taken by the Government prior to that date. Today the Treasurer came in here and repeated this pathetic excuse for lack of action by this Government. The truth is that he was not prepared to have a go. The Government lacked the will to get after these people who were defrauding the tax revenue of this country to the disadvantage of the wage and salary earners paying their tax regularly week after week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pretty much like Barwick.

—Actually, the interjection from the honourable member for Hawker is, unusually, not correct in this sense in that, bad as the High Court of Australia may have been at that stage under Sir Garfield Barwick, there was nothing that Sir Garfield Barwick ever did that would have, in fact, prevented this Government from prosecuting people for criminal offences.
—What about his cousin, Ellicott?

—He might have knowledge that we did not have. The honourable member for Port Adelaide has referred to another eminent legal mind! After that slight diversion I ask: How can the Treasurer reject legal opinions when not one person was prosecuted? He must be the one who possesses all legal knowledge. The matter was not tested because this Government was running dead on the issue allowing wage and salary earners to pay the burden of crushing taxation while tax avoiders and evaders continued to defraud the Commonwealth of revenue. The attitude that is adopted by the Government and by the Australian Taxation Office in respect of failing to prosecute people involved in multi-billion dollar frauds is very different from the attitude that it adopts to people who may, for some reason, find it difficult to pay tax. SPEECH.PARA: Another indication of that approach is an answer to a question on 20 April this year in the Senate. Senator Grimes asked the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) how many prosecutions occurred for offences under the Social Services Act in 1980-81. The answer by Senator Chaney was 1,299. That is an indication of what the Government is like when it is dealing with aged pensioners, invalid pensioners, widowed pensioners, unemployment beneficiaries, sickness beneficiaries, special beneficiaries and all other recipients of benefits under that legislation. The Government is quite prepared to have a go there. But it comes in here and says: 'Oh, well, there is no basis under which we can proceed until we pass legislation'. Let us see what happened when the Government did pass the legislation. The fact is that the Government has only two alternatives here: Either the Treasurer knew what was going on and did nothing or he should have known and did nothing. In both cases the Treasurer should, in fact, resign. Let us go back to 26 November when the Treasurer came into this House--

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't even say that with conviction.

—Was that the honourable member for Bendigo? Let us go back to 26 November when the Treasurer came into this House with his much-vaunted legislation-the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill 1980. The reason for that legislation was the claim by the Treasurer that without it the Government could not act against those defrauding the Commonwealth of revenue. That claim was nonsense then, as it is now. As I have outlined today the legal advice which was given to the Government was totally ignored by it because it wanted to protect certain people. The honourable member for Fremantle pointed that out earlier today too.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened since the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill was passed by this House? That legislation was going to solve all the problems. That legislation, according to the Treasurer, was the legislation which would fix it all up. It is now more than 20 months since that legislation was passed and still there has been not one prosecution. The Treasurer claims, without any justification, that he could not act prior to that Bill being passed. What is the excuse now? After 20 months the tax avoidance industry is still flourishing but this Government has not launched one prosecution. The attitude of the Government and in particular the Treasurer on this crucial issue was demonstrated by the reaction of the Treasurer to the McCabe-Lafranchi report. The Treasurer's first response was to brand it as a political stunt. As late as 29 May last, he was still claiming that, prior to the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, there was no effective measure whereby he could prosecute the people involved in this sort of scheme. He was still peddling that desperate defence of his Government's hopeless record of inactivity today in this Parliament. He seems to be determined to continue to push it.

On 4 June, to comment again on the McCabe-Lafranchi report, we saw the attitude of the Treasurer demonstrated again. The Treasurer said on that day that he could not explain why no attempt was made to put at least a sample of the companies into liquidation. If such action had been taken the liquidator would have had far wider powers than exist under the Income Tax Assessment Act. This Government failed not only to prosecute either prior to or after the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act but also to take normal steps to recover the money defrauded by those associated with the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Only one of the 923 companies involved in the McCabe-Lafranchi report was put into liquidation. This Government not only stood by and allowed the Commonwealth of Australia to be subjected to grotesque tax avoidance schemes but also, having watched the money disappear, has not taken the basic action required to recover it. Let your friends take it and then make sure they keep it is the philosophy of this disgraced government on this issue.

Today we heard the Treasurer seeking refuge in section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I will deal with that. If that section is the problem, it is time the secrecy provisions were reviewed. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has demonstrated that access to tax records enabled it to expose criminal offences. That in itself is a strong case that, subject to supervision by requiring applications to the courts, access to tax files should be allowed for other law enforcement agencies. In any event, surely we are not expected to believe that that section requires the Treasurer to shut his eyes to massive frauds on Commonwealth revenue. Personal details of individual persons must be protected. But section 16 is not an excuse for the Treasurer to pretend that he was the member of an exclusive club of about four people who did not know what was going on-that is, massive tax avoidance. The anti-secrecy provisions of the Act did not prevent the Costigan Royal Commission opening up the facts of that massive fraud. On the issue of secrecy, page 94 of Volume I of Interim Report No. 4 of the Costigan Royal Commission states:

I am of the view that the secrecy provisions of Section 16 cannot be justified; whereas their replacement by provisions that ensure true privacy of the information may be. The absolute bar should be removed.
Further in that report, at page 95, the Royal Commissioner deals with the second part of the secrecy provision. The report states:
The second aspect of the secrecy provisions is the part preventing the Minister of the Crown from exercising supervisory powers over the administration of his department.
At that stage the Commissioner says:

No doubt it was initially thought that if a Minister had access to the Taxation records of individuals he may be tempted to use them for political purposes. I believe that that is quite unlikely to occur, but I have no doubt that appropriate protections against such possible clause could be inserted into the Income Tax Act.

The fact is that the argument which is being used here today about the secrecy provisions being the reason that action was not taken is, in fact, absolute nonsense. In relation to that, I would also like to refer to the statement of the Treasurer. On 27 June, in statement No. 103, the Treasurer dealt with this issue of company stripping. In the statement he indicated that a case of company stripping first came to the attention of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation early in 1973. He then dealt with the investigation which took place. He went on to say that the Deputy Commissioner received an opinion in January 1975 to the effect that on the material presented grounds existed for prosecution under section 67 of the Companies Act and section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that proceedings could be instituted under section 367B of the Companies Act . Here is somebody else giving an opinion to the Treasurer in relation to this matter which he has chosen, again, to ignore. As I have said he thinks they are all wrong and he is the only one who is right. He went on to say:

Having checked that secrecy provisions would not operate as a barrier to prosecution, in August 1975, the Commissioner authorised the Deputy Crown Solicitor to take the necessary steps towards action under the indicated sections of the Crimes Act and the Companies Act.

It is absolute nonsense for the Treasurer to be coming in here today and saying- and for other members opposite to be pretending-that section 16 is an excuse for them not to take action in relation to the matters we are discussing today. In concluding I come back to a crucial point and that is the finding of the Costigan Royal Commission that the schemes referred to could have been prosecuted under the law that existed prior to the passing of the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act in 1980. Today the Treasurer, Mr Howard, cast some doubts on that opinion of Mr Costigan. We are now expected to believe that all the legal opinions, including Mr Costigan's, are wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he is right.

—Exactly, the Treasurer is right! But at no stage has the Treasurer told this Parliament what opinion he relies upon to support his now utterly desperate attempt to defend the failure of the Government to prosecute criminals . If, in fact, the Treasurer has an opinion which casts doubts on the opinions given in 1978 by the Melbourne Q.C., by Mr Forsyth and by Mr Davies, and the opinion referred to in the Press release of the Treasurer of 27 June, it is about time he came into the Parliament and told us whose opinion it is, because it must be a ripper.
—It's Malcolm's.

—It could well be. I assume that the honourable member for Port Adelaide, in referring to Malcolm, is referring to the Prime Minister. He may have belted out an opinion on it. But, on a serious note, we ought to know whose opinion it is because it seems to run against all the other opinions that have been given to date. The day of reckoning for this Government came not because of the fact that it decided that it would take any action. It came as a result of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and that of the Costigan Royal Commission. Without those reports this Government would have continued to do nothing about the massive fraud of public funds that we have seen in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the House has been discussing very grave issues. In my judgment they represent as grave a collection of issues as I have heard examined in my time in this House. That being the case, I would like to approach this debate by stating what I would apprehend to be the basic philosophy of all men and women of good will. The first is that one can never hold a society together unless one lays down and prescribes that certain canons of conduct will be observed. I have no sympathy whatsoever for those who believe that they can go their own wilful way and do whatever pleases them. I find myself at one with the view that men cannot enjoy the benefits of a civil and an uncivil society. If one wants to enjoy what advantages are offered by an uncivil society there is a price to be paid by that society and by people who commit the wrong-doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, and I have done so all of my life, that those who treat others unfairly are entitled to get their just deserts. I believe that those who indulge in improper and illegal practices deserve to meet with all of the sanctions of the law. I believe that those who break the law expose themselves to the penalty of the law. I believe that illegality is not to be tolerated. This may seem trite or humdrum to the majority of people but I believe it must be stated because it represents what I believe to be fundamental to the conduct and maintenance of any ordered and civil society. I am not aware of any system of jurisprudence that runs away from that. I am not aware of any politico-socio system that runs away from that-from the Plato, Aquinas or Austinian view of jurisprudence. Unless there is respect for order and unless the law is observed one will have breakdown of the society.

Grave charges have been discussed here today. They are allegations. I put emphasis on that because this goes to the maintenance of our society. The allegations involve fraud against the Crown, the Government and the people. The allegations involve resort to taxation evasion on a massive scale. This matter involves allegations of threats to individuals and allegations of murder, corruption and wickedness in high places. That would represent as grave a collection of issues as any civilised parliament could gaze upon and take into its thinking. That is the first basic principle that I lay down. If the Opposition is to present any indictment against the Government it will need to observe that that is the way which I hold and which I believe all of my colleagues hold and every person in this Parliament basically holds.

The second limb of philosophy that I want to examine is the role of the civil service. Allegations have been made against the civil service which would represent incompetence and negligence on a hitherto undiscovered scale. I have a very old fashioned view of the civil service. I believe that it must be responsive to the decree and determination of government and parliament. I believe that it has a duty to advise governments and Ministers. I believe it has a duty to caution, to warn and to counsel. But the towering duty of the civil service at the end of the day it is to obey the decision and the determination of government and parliament. The Public Service in a very real sense is a buckle between parliament and the will of the people.

I turn to the Royal Commision's report because in that report are the allegations involving corruption, fraud, tax evasion, incompetence and negligence. They are all there. The report represents the findings of a commissioner under no obligation whatsoever to proceed in the manner in which a court making a finding which would sheet home fraud and conspiracy charges would proceed. He proceeds on an entirely different basis. I am not conscious of having met any of the people who have been mentioned in the report or in the course of this debate. I speak from the basis of complete neutrality. There is a presumption. It is a very old one but it is a very precious one and all of us who sit in the House are under the plainest obligation to heed and respect it because, if we allow it to be diminished in any shape or form, we will turn back the clock centuries. It is the presumption of innocence. Whatever findings Mr Costigan of Queen's Counsel may make in this report, if any of the gentlemen or ladies involved in it appeared in a criminal court they would stand in the dock and have the presumption of innocence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Double standards.

—I do not want to upset my friend the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), but I listened to him, I thought, in complete silence. I am not seeking any indulgence from him but I am talking about grave matters. I want to discuss them as impartially as I possibly can. Mr Costigan has presided as a royal commissioner but he is observing, as I say, a completely different role from that of a judge or those sitting upon a jury. I refer the House to a very famous case-I trust that the lawyers will recall it-in which this matter was considered, that is, McGuinness against the Attorney-General of Victoria in 1940 . Chief Justice Latham-this is the principle I want the House to acknowledge- said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Crown has no prerogative power of establishing new courts and if it were attempted to confer upon a Royal Commission by order in council, or by any means short of a statute, the powers of a court . . . there is, in my opinion, no doubt that the commission would be unlawful in the sense that the attempt would fail.

The case was a consideration of an allegation of bribery of members of parliament so we may say that it could tax and concern us all. If a member of parliament is charged with bribery the commissioner may make a finding against him of bribery but when the man goes into the dock there is the presumption of innocence. Throughout the whole of that trial there is the presumption of innocence. I say to the House that not one word of this report would be admissible in a court of evidence. Mr Costigan turns to precisely that point in his report towards the end of his finding on this chapter. On page 100 he states :

I have not, in making this recommendation, adopted the procedure made available to me by the terms of reference to recommend specific prosecutions in this matter. There are several reasons why I have not done that: (a) in order to do it, I am required by the terms of reference to make such recommendations on the basis of admissible evidence.

The royal commissioner may make a finding based on hearsay piled upon hearsay. I do not know and I do not greatly care. But the Attorney-General is not at liberty to go on a frolic of his own no matter what the evidence given to or the findings of a royal commissioner may be. The Attorney-General of any State, and certainly of this country, stands quite differently from any member of the Cabinet. He is the pater patrial of the country and if he launches a prosecution he must launch it on admissible evidence that will stand up in a court. I join with honourable members on both sides of the House in stating that if there has been any culpability, all of the resources of the judicial process of this country can and should be invoked. I appeal to all honourable members to take some heed of the presumption of innocence.

This afternoon I listened to what I would describe as a conspicuously unpleasant speech by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), the new found Robespierre. It is very easy to name people in the Parliament. I wonder whether the honourable gentleman would be prepared to go outside the Parliament and make the same speech. That is one test of the honourable gentleman's sense of determination in this matter. Let me give him another. Why does he not ask each of his colleagues within the Australian Labor Party to donate $100 to enable the honourable gentleman to launch a private prosecution against the people he named in the Parliament today? Of course there is no presumption of innocence with the honourable gentleman. It is a presumption of guilt all the way through. Our law was not created on that basis, it has not been defended on that basis and it will certainly not be maintained on that basis.

I draw to the attention of the House what I thought was a very cogent argument put by my friend the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) this afternoon. He said: 'Well, if you want to impeach us you had better have a look at your own behaviour on the way'. This afternoon several honourable gentlemen opposite have tried to dismiss that by saying: 'Oh, but you know it was mentioned to us. We were the ones who took action'. The honourable member for Wills said: 'We got an opinion from Mr Brinsden'. He is now Mr Justice Brinsden of the Supreme Court of South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia. What does a State matter here or there? Don't let's be accurate geographically either.

—Facts have never greatly troubled the honourable gentleman. There was the opinion. It was given in 1974. The only explanation for no action being taken came from another honourable gentleman opposite who said: 'Well, we had other distractions in 1974'. As it happens the people of this country vindicated the action taken in 1975 on two occasions. Let the honourable gentleman put that in his pipe and smoke it. On page 27 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This scheme was first detected in a widespread manner by the Australian Taxation office in 1973.
On the same page the report states:

In 1973-74 the scheme appears to have been of relatively small proportions compared to later years. That may reflect merely a lack of knowledge of its full extent. As early as 1975 some 250 instances . . .
This is the year. On page 33 the report states:
. . . the Australian Taxation Office in Perth detected the operation of these schemes as early as 1973 . . .
Page 35 refers to the opinion sought from the then Mr Brinsden. It states:
Ultimately a brief was delivered to counsel. He was Mr Brinsden, Q.C., now Mr Justice Brinsden of the Western Australian Supreme Court.

I have referred to that because I thought that I would vindicate the honourable member for Wills on at least one occasion. If we turn to page 68 we find illustrations of the growth of Mr Todman's investigation. Finally, I draw the attention of the House to what was said by the Royal Commissioner at pages 79 and 87 of the report. What is the proposition? If honourable members opposite are going to inculpate Ministers on this side of the House what about their dereliction of duty in the years 1973-75? If we take this matter seriously-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read it? Go on, read it.

—I say to the honourable member for Wills that there is an old Chinese saying: 'You can always tell when you are out in front when the mob are throwing stones'. If the honourable member for Wills takes this view, why does he not put down in this House an address calling for the removal of Mr Justice Murphy, because he was the Attorney-General of the day? This point was made by the honourable member for Mitchell, and it was a very valid point indeed. I turn now to the observation made by the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) concerning section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. During this debate no mention has been made of what Mr Costigan said on page 10 of his report, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: In my third Interim Report I recommended that Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act be amended so as to allow this Commission access to records held by the Australian Taxation Office. That recommendation was considered by Government and Section 16 was amended so as to allow me conditional access.

The final objection that Mr Costigan makes about section 16 is to the effect that although he acknowledges the help that it has been to him and says that he has found it very valuable, he goes on to make the point that it does not enable him to fulfil all of his duties. He makes the following objection:

I have raised these matters because although the access provided to me has indeed been valuable, it has become apparent that there are limitations on that access which do seriously impede the usefulness of it. To remove these restrictions would not in my view be contrary to the public interest. Indeed I would say positively that it would be to the publc interest if some of the information I am acquiring from the Taxation office could be ventilated publicly .

I want to make the point that from 1973 until the time when the Act was amended that difficulty was there. Costigan is still of the opinion that the difficulty remains although in a quietened form. He refers to and cites a stream of cases to the effect that, irrespective of that amendment, prosecutions could well have been launched. That is his opinion. I suppose one could get an opinion to the contrary. It is a very valid point to consider whether there should be a strengthening of section 16 as amended. That is a case that can be put to the Treasurer (Mr Howard). It should be put on its merits, not on the basis of saying: 'Well, we knew all along'. Other people were exposed to the limitations of section 16-Mr Frank Crean, Dr Cairns, Sir Phillip Lynch--

TALK.START.PARA: —Billy Hughes.

—Well, I say to the House that legend has it that the honourable member for Port Adelaide was known in the bush as 'Five out' because every time the sheep were counted at the end of a run, the boss of the board would query: 'How many, Young?'. He was shearing light ewes in those days too. If he said there were 45, the boss would say: 'I am very sorry, I make it 40'. He was always five out and he was five out when he supported the honourable member for Wills.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to where I started. This has been and remains a very grave day for the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. Issues have been raised and undertakings have been given by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that there will be complete prosecution according to the law. But I say to all honourable members in the House: If we seek to diminish, destroy or ignore the basic presumption of innocence we will turn back, literally by centuries, the clock of the traditions of our people.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Student Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will:

1. Restrict Access to Education. People from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts. These people, if they enrol, will be forced to amass loan debts. Richer students do not face this handicap.

2. Undermine the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. TEAS should cover the basic living costs of students. Currently the scheme only assists 38% of full- time students and the maximum level of TEAS is a mere $49.67. Government statements indicate TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.

3. Disadvantage Women. Women students would be disadvantaged by a loans scheme as they have a lesser ability to repay loan debts, because on average women earn less and have a higher unemployment rate.

4. Disadvantage Mature-Age Students. Usually mature age students forgo income to study and already have large financial commitments. They could not return to study if it meant incurring substantial debts.
5. Distort Educational Choices. Mounting loan debts would force students into studying shorter courses or not continuing with post-graduate study.

6. Result in Massive Attrition Rates. Students will attempt to undertake extensive part-time work or overload courses to minimise their loans. Increased failure rates will result forcing students to ''drop-out'' rather than continuing study and increase their debts.

7. Cause Administrative and Financial Difficulties. Overseas experience shows high default rates will occur on student loans. Government money will be channelled away from TEAS to paying off banks. The government will also bear the administrative burden of pursuing defaulters.
Therefore, the proposed student loans scheme will have disastrous effects on tertiary education, which we believe benefits the whole community, not just the individual student.
The House of Representatives will reject the introduction of a student loans scheme. And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Dawkins.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Wine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that any sales tax or excise on Australian wine would adversely affect employment in the retail liquor industry, substantially decrease retail sales through a reduction in the demand for wine and threaten the viability of many wine merchants;
the reduction in the demand for wine will also threaten the existence of many wine producers and reduce the range, quality and variety of wines offered in the market.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will reject any proposal for a sales tax or excise on Australian wine:
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Howard.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the current rates of personal income tax are onerous and destructive of personal incentive, particularly since the cessation of income tax indexation,
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call upon the Parliament assembled to legislate such changes to the current taxation law as will
raise the minimum level at which income tax is first payable to at least $4,500 .00,
proportionately increase the figures at which the higher rates of tax attract,
allow taxpayers to claim the full amount for each item within the Concessional Expenditure Rebate, and
adjust the rates of tax payable so that no higher rate of tax is payable than fifty per cent of income earned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr MacKellar and Mr Leo McLeay.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are concerned that an increasing number of Australian families are facing financial burdens beyond their capacity to meet.
2. That we are concerned that the amount of financial assistance being afforded to families is inadequate.
3. That there has been no increase in family allowances for most families for some years.
4. That family allowances in all instances have declined in real value since 1976.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will:
1. Ensure that there is an increase in family allowances in the 1982 Budget so that family allowances are at least restored to the real money value of their 1976 level;
2. Ensure that provision is made for the automatic and regular indexation of family allowances;
3. Ensure that proper consideration is given to the introduction of a Homemakers Allowance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Deposit Assistance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) The restrictive income test of the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme penalises applicants who are forced by rising housing prices and high interest rates to become two-income families;
(2) the limit on the value of the house be reintroduced to ensure that the wealthy would not be eligible to apply for the grant;
(3) the interest rate tax rebate is too low and takes too long to recompense to be of any real value to low-income earners, who cannot afford the repayments of a high interest loan; and
(4) more people should be made eligible for the loan so that the building industry may be assisted out of its present slump.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House request the Government to take positive steps to stimulate the waning building undustry and genuinely assist home buyers by raising, or abolishing, the income test, re-introducing a limit on the value of the house and increasing the tax rebate of the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and (b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require

(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and (b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the shortage of staff members in the Department of Social Security has resulted in poor service to clients and delays in payment of benefits.
That the recent standdowns of staff of the Department of Social Security have exacerbated the above situation and caused undue hardship to pensioners and beneficiaries.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) Staffing levels in the Department be increased to a level acceptable to staff members.
(2) The Government demonstrate its concern for clients by rescinding the standdowns and allowing staff back to work with no loss of salary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Austrlia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the south west of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth their anger and condemnation at the unrealistic low priority given to children's vacation programmes and other children's services which has resulted in the withdrawal of funds from programmes which provide an essential community service.
We protest at the disastrous effects this will have on parents and children.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government provide public funding for all children's services including vacation programmes to ensure quality services are available for all children and parents who require it.
Further that funds be immediately released to prevent closure of vacation programmes for the 1981-82 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for Children's services be spent in full for the purposes designed.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In Vitro Fertilisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned show that as the treatment, in Vitro Fertilisation and Embryo Transfer (commonly referred to as the Test Tube Baby Program) is bringing new hope to infertile couples, and leads the world in this method, we therefore wish to voice our support for the IVP and ET program.

Your petitioners therefore pray that this supplication is accepted and that no action to restrict or ban the IVF and ET Program, both at this time and in the future, will be taken until a National Referendum is held on the 'Test Tube Baby ' Program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Australian Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of Australia showeth that:
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the increasing levels of direct and indirect taxation.
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the increasingly inequitable distribution of these taxes through the Social Wage.
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the apparently uncontrolled increases in interest rates and the shrinking access to loan capital.
Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at the neglect of pension levels and the absence of real relativity with average wages.

Members of the community are concerned and alarmed at diminishing government spending on Health, its consequential effect on the quality, cost and availability of health services and the absence of meaningful expenditure for the prevention of disease and injury.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia by this humble petition respectfully pray that the Australian Government introduce tax indexation on personal income tax scales and the tax free threshold.

Introduce 1. Broadly based wealth tax exempting small holdings. 2. Capital Gains tax exempting owner occupied homes. 3. The closing of tax loopholes which enable company and high earner tax avoidance. 4. A resources tax or excess profit tax.
The Australian Government raise the single pensions and benefits to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings over the next three years.

The Australian Government institute wider controls over interest rates charged by all lending institutions and pass legislation which will allow for a fixed percentage of all available loan capital to be held in reserve for the purpose of owner occupied home loans.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, members of the National Council of Women of Australia, respectfully showeth that :
(i) many threats to peace exist in our international community;
(ii) great sums of money are expended by Governments throughout the world on the development and production of arms;
(iii) increasing numbers of people are suffering from extreme poverty, malnutrition and disease.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Commonwealth of Australia
Work for the cessation of all hostilities so that people may live without fear and with hope for the future
Strive for strict control throughout the world of nuclear and chemical weapons and other weapons of mass destruction;
Promote studies and research programs to investigate the feasibility of a production change from arms to goods which change would service to benefit mankind.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned electors of the division of Richmond respectfully showeth-The old age pension is granted according to the Constitution of the Land, Federal Parliament and the people, conditionally to all citizens, who were non serving members of the forces, on reaching 65 years of age. We of the past forces, are entitled to the above named pension five years earlier; at 60 years of age. An unconditional pension is granted to those who did not serve in the forces at the age of 70 years . . . a time difference of 5 years.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you, our Honourable Member, will bring this matter before the attention of the Minister for Veterans Affairs, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proserpine Post Office, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Dawson Electorate of North Queensland respectfully showeth- that Post Offices are the responsibility of the Federal Government,
the Proserpine Post Office has inadequate access for a large number of the community
