PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth: That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are outraged and disturbed by the inhumane slaughter of baby harp seals off the coasts of Newfoundland and in particular, the Gulf of St Lawrence and the Magdelen Islands.
1. That, as a people of a democratic society, we urge the Australian Government to halt all imports of seal products.
2. That we can be assured that the murdering of harp seals be discontinued in all forms at the real and perilous threat of the extinction of yet another Arctic animal species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government take heed of their petitioners' protest, and give seals the right to life.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1982 is the first tax Bill for this new session. It deals with seven matters relating to the Income Tax Assessment Act, none of which is very controversial and none of which the Opposition opposes. As well as futher amendments relating to tax avoidance schemes, which I will turn to shortly, the Bill exempts from tax certain foreign pensions related to war time persecution; extends the gift deductibility provisions of the Act; makes further amendments to the secrecy provisions of section 16-a matter which has been the focus of discussion this afternoon; extends tax exemption to the income of the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd; proposes amendments to Division 7 tax arrangements for private companies; and exempts from tax profits made on the sale or redemption of securities purchased or acquired at a discount before 30 June of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of these provisions need little explanation. The Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd is an Australian Government-owned and controlled company which was set up in June 1981 to replace, by agreement with New Zealand, the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission as the body responsible for phosphate mining on the island. The Commission is exempt from tax, as is all activity on Christmas Island. The purpose of this legislation is to transfer to the new company exemption which applied to the Commission. As regards the exemption from tax of certain pensions, section 23 (k) (c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act currently exempts pensions paid by a State of the Federal German Republic as compensation to victims of national socialist persecution. This Bill proposes to extend exemptions provided by that section to give general exception to pensions , annuities and allowances paid under foreign law that are related to or take into account enemy persecution during the Second World War or disability arising from participation in a resistance movement against enemy forces during that war . Both of these measures, are, of course, totally acceptable to the Opposition.

Another of the amendments proposed is that where the Commissioner of Taxation is satisfied that tax avoidance is not involved payment of dividends by way of an issue of shares or debentures will be taken into account in determining sufficient distribution for Division 7 tax purposes. In addition, section 78 of the Act which provides tax deductibility for gifts to a wide range of institutions will be extended to authorise deductions for gifts to the Connellan Airways Trust, the Queensland Cultural Centre Trust, Polish relief appeals and relief appeals established in response to the cyclone disaster in Tonga and the Falkland Islands dispute. Again neither of these sets of amendments is opposed. It is interesting to note, however, that although these measures were announced well before the Budget, no estimates have been provided in the Budget for the likely cost to revenue which each will bring about. That of course is not new. This point further illustrates the need to adopt a taxation expenditure budget such as is widely used overseas and has been proposed by the Opposition to monitor the cost to revenue of all forms of concessions provided through the tax system.

This Government, since coming in to office, has provided an extensive array of tax concessions to various groups in the community and has been very reluctant to provide full information as to the cost of such concessions. A series of questions on notice which I put to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) last year indicated that the Australian Taxation Office is capable of costing fewer than 50 per cent of the tax concessions contained in the Income Tax Assessment Act. This situation is quite unacceptable and taxpayers deserve to know just who is benefiting from assistance provided through the tax system in the same way as detailed information is provided with regard to direct expenditure programs. In the Budget Papers we have an enormous amount of detail about the cost of all sorts of expenditures but, on the tax concession side, a lot of them remain hidden even though each year more information is provided than in the previous year. We applaud that development but say it should go much further to the point of having a taxation expenditure budget.

A further provision of the Act proposes amendments to section 16 relating to the secrecy provision of the Act. Section 16 provides strict prohibitions against divulging taxation information except to authorised recipients of such information as set out in the Act. One of these authorised recipients is the Commonwealth Statistician who can be provided with taxation information relating to the names and addresses of employers and the nature of the industry in which that person is involved for use in relation to employment statistics. This amendment proposes to extend these existing provisions in two ways: Firstly, to allow this information to be used by the statistician for statistical purposes and, secondly, to authorise the provision of additional employment information, specifically the number of male and female employees for pay-as-you-earn purposes. Labor strongly supports the secrecy provisions of the Act and is concerned to ensure that they are not unnecessarily eroded. We do however support amendments to this section, where they are strongly justified. This was shown by our support earlier this year from amendments arising from recommendations made by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to enhance the effectiveness of crime detection and prosecution. In this light we will give the closest consideration to further recommendations regarding this provision arising out of yesterday's tabled report of the royal commission. The current amendment before the House is a minor one aimed at ensuring a more efficient collection of comprehensive employment statistics. We do not oppose this provision.

It is interesting to note that one of the more important sections of this Bill is yet another amendment relating to measures directed against tax avoidance. The Treasurer claimed in the Budget that tax avoidance in Australia is now dead. Accordingly, the Budget makes no allowance this year for revenue losses resulting from tax avoidance. That of course is in stark contrast to previous Budgets. Last year's Budget, for example, made a specific allowance of $300m for revenue shortfalls attributable to tax avoidance. The Budget before last allowed for revenue losses of $290m. These figures were gross underestimates of the likely revenue losses resulting from tax avoidance in each year. More realistic estimates of the magnitude of tax avoidance put revenue losses at around $3,000m a year.

Australia's most noted taxation authority, Professor Mathews from the Australian National University, has developed a method of estimating tax avoidance losses by comparing the total tax shares paid by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers and non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, that is, those persons with incomes from property, business and dividends. Using Professor Mathews' technique, revenue losses due to tax avoidance during 1981-82 were around $3,300m. Figures of that magnitude are supported by Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association. It is absolutely absurd that the treasurer can declare that tax avoidance has virtually overnight changed from being an industry of massive proportions to being virtually non-existent.

On what does the Treasurer base these claims? It would seem that he is relying on three major pieces of legislation which have been introduced by the Government in the last two years. These are the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, which of course has been very much before the House in this afternoon's discussions, the new general anti-avoidance section, part IVA, which was introduced in the middle of last year and finally the re-written section 136 against transfer pricing practices which was introduced earlier this year. While these provisions have a potentially wide impact, they have yet to be tested. It is quite ridiculous that measures which were touted with such fanfare by the Treasurer at the time have been in existence for such a considerable period without being put to the test. It is obvious that there has been ample time to arrange a test case for these provisions, but the Government seems totally unwilling to subject these provisions to the scrutiny of the courts.

At the time when these provisions were introduced, the Australian Labor Party, while strongly supporting their intent, was concerned that major deficiencies existed in each of them which could potentially lead to their reading down by the courts. In addition, prominent tax lawyers also pointed out major defects in the legislation. Because the Government has yet to use any of these measures, it is possible only to assume that it shares the same doubts about their effectiveness. While these provisions in their current form may provide some deterrent to tax avoidance, it is certainly not possible to say that they have spelt the end of the tax avoidance industry.

For example, a press report earlier this month-it is pretty recent stuff- revealed that the Federal Taxation Office has identified 100 tax avoidance schemes used by high income earners in the past five years. The report goes on to state that only about half of these schemes have been legislated against. This is absolutely right. There have been about 50 schemes legislated against in the last five years. While officials believe that the general anti-avoidance section may cover some of the others, they are concerned about some of the schemes which are still being used. Furthermore, the report goes on to say that it is too early to identify new schemes used by taxpayers in the year just ended . The Treasurer reinforced the impression created by this report when he would not give an assurance in the Parliament last week that it would not be faced with further massive and complex pieces of legislation dealing with even more tax avoidance schemes. It is obvious from that that he is not confident about the effectiveness of his own measures regarding tax avoidance.

From the information that I have gathered it seems that the use of blatant and artificial paper schemes may be declining. That is not to say that such schemes are dead, but simply that more extremely blatant varieties have given way to more sophisticated attempts to disguise tax avoidance with some degree of commercial rationale. A major area of concern, however, is the proliferation of tax shelters which use concessions provided by the Act in a way in which they were not intended so as to minimise or defer tax, often indefinitely. Such shelters cover a wide variety of activities, such as boat building, breeding racehorses and agriculture to oil exploration and, more recently, film production. The Government must bear the responsibility for much of the revenue losses resulting from this form of tax avoidance because in the first place it provided the concessions which are being abused. Such concessions must be strictly monitored to ensure that they are not misused for tax avoidance purposes. In addition, there is a major concern within the Taxation Office at the wide use of overseas tax havens to avoid tax. This form of tax avoidance relies on the abuse of section 23 (q), which basically says that Australian individuals and companies who earn income overseas can, in most cases, bring their income back into Australia free of tax provided that it is taxed overseas no matter how low the tax rate which is applied overseas.

This provision acts as an incentive to shift income which would otherwise be taxed in Australia to tax havens overseas where it is taxed at a very low rate before being brought back into this country. The anti-transfer pricing provisions adopted earlier this year have had little impact on this practice. It is essential that a system of foreign tax credits requiring Australians with foreign source income to pay tax at full rates in Australia with credit for any tax paid overseas be introduced to prevent such abuses. Furthermore, there is a wide variety of tax avoidance structures being openly utilised in Australia with the full consent of the present Government. Particularly notable in this area is the use of internal superannuation funds and trusts which provide lucrative tax avoidance avenues for high income earners. In these circumstances, for the Treasurer to talk about tax avoidance being dead is nothing short of ridiculous. Only a comprehensive set of policies, such as those recently released publicly by the Opposition centering on fully retrospective legislation against tax avoidance schemes, an effective general anti-avoidance provision, specific action against schemes condoned by this Government and other strong measures, would be capable of ensuring that tax avoidance in Australia is stopped once and for all.

The tax avoidance measures proposed by this Bill involve further extension of legislation introduced as far back as September 1978 against expenditure recoupment type tax avoidance schemes. These schemes generally seek a deduction for some payment under an arrangement whereby the taxpayer or associate obtains some form of compensating benefit which effectively recoups the initial outgoing . Since the original legislation in 1978 there have been several further amendments dealing with particular variations of this scheme, the latest involving exploitation of tax concessions for shares in afforestation and petroleum exploration companies, which will be outlawed back to the original date of the legislation in 1978. We do not oppose that amendment. However, this measure clearly illustrates the ineffective nature of this Government's policy against tax avoidance simply by the fact that the Treasurer has been forced to legislate continuously since 1978 against new variants on the old schemes. Surely it is time for a new approach to combating tax avoidance to put an end to this dog chasing its own tail picture of the Government's inefficiency.

The final amendment which I propose to deal with relates to the sale or redemption of discounted securities. This year the Taxation Office, apparently for the first time, included with its instructions for filling out income tax returns the following statement:
Profits derived from the redemption at par of securities issued or acquired at a discount, are regarded as being in the nature of interest.

In other words, profits made on the redemption of discounted Commonwealth bonds and other securities were to be taxable. Honourable members will be very much aware that this statement provoked a storm of protest. For a long period it seems that it has been accepted practice that profits made on the redemption of such securities are capital profits and thus non-taxable. It seems that the Taxation Office has never advised investors in this way but has in the past simply failed to follow through this issue and actively enforce the tax laws by taxing such profits. According to the Taxation Office the statement in this year 's instructions on tax returns did not represent a change in interpretation of the provisions of the tax Act or reflect any changes in the law. Rather the statement was made to highlight the fact that such gains were taxable. It is obvious that the Taxation Office has become concerned at the large number of investors purchasing such securities in order to make what they thought were tax -free capital gains.

In a period of rapidly rising interest rates such as we have had in Australia over recent years the market price for such securities falls in order to maintain an attractive rate of return and consequently the profit on redemption, which is the difference between the face value of the coupon and the market price at which it was purchased, increases offering greater profit to the investor. In this situation the Taxation Office has forseen prospective large losses to revenue from this source unless quick action is taken. In a period of more stable interest rates, profits on such securities obviously would be less and thus the Taxation Office apparently has not been concerned in the past to ensure that such profits are fully taxed. As we understand it, for a long period most investment advisers have advised clients that returns on these securities are not taxable. Government stock prospectus also failed to state that profits made on redemption are taxable. When all these facts are considered it is possible to see where confusion has arisen.

Perhaps I should illustrate in more detail the problem which has arisen. Let us take, for example, the situation of Commonwealth bonds due to mature in, say, May 1989 at their face value of $100 which had been selling for, say $74. These bonds pay $9.70 per anum interest and when redeemed in 1989 are worth $100. Up to now it has been generally accepted in the investing community that the $9.70 interest each year is taxable but the $26 extra received in 1989 is tax-free capital. It is easy to see how such bonds are attractive to persons nearing retirement who want to minimise their income for pension purposes but preserve the value of their capital against inflation. When the Taxation Office announced its move in this area there was a reaction from the investing public who had bought such securities on the understanding that the profit was tax free. The Treasurer then overruled the Taxation Office and declared that such profits would not be taxable in the 1981-82 income year but would be taxable from 30 June onwards. To give effect to the Treasurer's statement it has been necessary to specifically exempt such profits from tax for the period in question.

This exemption does not apply to profits made by dealers or traders in securities and profits under section 26AAA which relates to the 12-month capital gains provision, section 26c which relates to certain non-interest-bearing Commonwealth Securities and stock, or section 26 (a) which relates to profit- making undertakings or schemes involving the use of such securities. These sections effectively ensure that persons using such securities on a large scale as a major source of income will be subjected to tax. From 30 June this year all profits arising in this way will be assessable either under those sections-the capital gains sections-or under section 25, which generally brings to account all sources of assessable income. As with all other measures contained in this Bill the Labor Party supports this amendment on the grounds that it seems reasonable to make the exemption provided for by the Treasurer up until the end of the last financial year. But from now, of course, all such profits will be taxable, and rightly so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Australian Labor Party is not opposing the bulk of the measures contained in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4). I stress that I think the bulk of the measures are non- controversial. The disclosure of information to the Australian Statistician obviously is a matter which is widely supported. The exemption of the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd obviously is acceptable. The exemption regarding foreign pensions related to war time persecution clearly is a matter which is supported by the House. I am glad to hear that the provision regarding the sale of securities purchased at a discount is supported by the Australian Labor Party. It is reasonable for the Government to make the appropriate change in this matter because there was widespread expectation, as pointed out by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), that there would be the capacity for this capital profit in terms of the difference between the discounted price and the redemption price. The expectation was that this capital profit would be free of income tax. Those people who bought in expectation of that tax-free gain are now to be protected. In future, of course, this protection will not exist. At least people will be aware of the rules of the game.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense, that is the essential difference between the approach of this Government and that of the Opposition to taxation. Under our system we take the view that it is right and proper to know what the rules of the game really are, and that the rules should not be changed after the game has been part played. The Australian Labor Party takes a totally different view. The honourable member for Gellibrand made these points very forcefully. He said, for example, that it is time to take a new approach, that it is not good enough for the Government to be forced to legislate on new variations in respect of tax-avoidance arrangements since 1978 and that the Labor Party supports the introduction of fully retrospective legislation in order to cope with tax avoidance problems. In other words, the Opposition's dedicated commitment is to changing the rules after people have entered into arrangements.

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Gellibrand restating that position very forcefully tonight. It demonstrates a dramatic difference between the two parties on this matter. To make illegal something that was legal at the time is a matter which I think should exercise our minds and concern everone who is interested in the rule of law. There have been allegations that the Federal Government is looking at plans for retrospective recoupment in respect of bottom -of-the-harbour schemes and funds which at the time were not regarded as taxable but which are now regarded by the Commisioner of Taxation as recoupable. That is regarded by many people as retrospective legislation. I seek to distinguish very clearly, for the benefit of the Opposition, between a generally retrospective approach as outlined tonight by the honourable member for Gellibrand and the sort of approach which the Federal Government supports.

The Government's approach is very simple. It takes the view that if one does something which is legal at the time it cannot be made illegal. The reason that the Government supports recoupment-it is a subject about which there is some disagreement in the community at the moment-is that the recoupment relates to schemes which always were illegal. There has never been any suggestion that bottom-of-the-harbour schemes ever were legal. There has never been any suggestion that they do not offend the Crimes Acts or Companies Acts in the various States, including the Commonwealth Act. There is no doubt that if one's concern is recoupment there is no benefit in seeking recoupment from promoters who undertook these frauds because the promoters did not end up with the benefit . The people who ended up with the benefit were the people who sold the company structures to them and who did not enter into fraud or do anything illegal. This is the dilemma that any government in this situation must face. The people who received the benefit were not the people who perpetrated the fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were Patrick Partners in it?
—I am interested to hear the interjection from the honourable member because he is incapable of answering any case without interposing personal abuse . It does not surprise me that the only comment--
—I just wanted to know whether Patrick Partners were in it.

—The only comment the honourable member can make in this or any other moment relates specifically to an attempt to denigrate me or any member of this side who is endeavouring to make a serious and sensible point relating to policy and the best interests of this nation.
—I just asked you an innocent question: Were Patrick Partners involved?
—The honourable member places himself within the contempt of the House by his persistent interjections.
—You have obviously got a guilty conscience.
—The honourable member for Chifley will remain silent. The honourable member for Macarthur may proceed. I suggest that he ignore the interjections.

—In this context I mention only that there has been a concerted campaign by the honourable member for Chifley, amongst others, to interject on that level. I suggest that that determined and deliberate campaign is aimed at denigrating the status of this House and it certainly lowers his esteem in this place.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The abuse being levelled at me is a personal reflection on me. I ask you to request the honourable member for Macarthur to withdraw those remarks.

—Order! The honourable member for Chifley will resume his seat . In the opinion of the Chair there is no reflection other than that invited. I ask the honourable member for Chifley to remain silent. I again exhort the honourable member for Macarthur to ignore the interjections.

—The problem the Government faces is simply this: The people who benefited from the fraud were not those who perpetrated it. Therefore, if the object of the Government is to seek recoupment of that money, there is no benefit in attacking the promoters in regard to recoupment. There may well be personal satisfaction involved, and the Government is pursuing that matter in order to ensure that there can be no view in the community that those who perpetrate frauds on the revenue can get away scot-free. However, the essence of the difference between the Opposition's position and our position is this: We take the view that we have a right to seek recoupment of money that has been fraudulently obtained even though the persons who got the benefit were not involved in a fraud. The Opposition takes the view that it can change the rules after the event. They assert that a legal act can magically be transformed into an illegal one after the event. It is like driving down a road at 80 kilometres per hour because that is the speed limit and suddenly finding after the event that one has been arrested because the speed limit was reduced to 60 kilometres per hour after one started one's journey.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a sensible and rational basis for distinguishing between the Opposition's approach to overall retrospectivity in tax matters-it raised this matter again tonight-and the Government's strong view that it has an entitlement to recoup money that was returned to vendors who may well have been innocent but who received the benefit of a fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister says that he supports retrospective legislation. Do you disagree with him?

—To correct the honourable member for Gellibrand, I pointed out that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that he supports legislation which may have some retrospective impact. There is no doubt that there is some retrospective impact, and it would be nonsense to deny it. In a situation such as this, people who believe they have done nothing wrong but have benefited from a fraud are required to pay that money back. We may just as well say that the person in the pub-I used this analogy the other night-who bought a watch from someone for $30 knowing it to be a $1,000 watch may well say that he did nothing wrong. He has done nothing wrong; he has bought a watch. However, when the original owner finds out that he has that watch, the original owner has every right to seek the return-the recoupment-of that watch.

SPEECH.PARA: I was intrigued to hear various members of the Opposition allege that the buyer of the watch was somehow guilty and that the people who in fact sold companies are viciously guilty of a conspiracy or some other crime when in fact they sold in the understanding that that sale was legal and proper. It seems to me that the Opposition, by its attitude in this afternoon's debate, accused the people involved in selling these companies of criminal behaviour. That attitude seems to me to pervade the Opposition's attitude to tax measures. There was nothing illegal in what the vendors did. This Government does not suggest there was anything illegal; it is simply saying that the proceeds of fraud, which may well have innocently flowed to these people, should be recouped.

There is no nexus between recoupment and fault. There is no nexus between recoupment and criminality, and yet the Labor Party seeks to draw that nexus. The Labor Party has accused people in this House and used their names in this House. It has accused them of criminality when what they did did not offend against any law. That is the approach of the Labor Party. We will find the names -if this approach continues-of innocent people, who have done things that were quite lawful, dragged through the mud by the Opposition, as they were this afternoon, if the Opposition gets on to the Treasury benches. Opposition members have said that they will make this sort of legislation totally retrospective. They will make this sort of legislation totally retrospective. SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to refer briefly to clause 5 of the Income Tax Assessment Bill ( No. 4) which proposes to amend the principal Act to insert a new section 23J to exempt from income tax profits made on the sale or redemption of debt securities acquired at a discount on or before 30 June 1982, subject to certain exemptions. I am sorry that the honourable member for Macarthur has shown such little interest in the debate and has now left the chamber because what I want to say goes ultimately to the question of retrospectivity that he seemed to be so concerned about. The proposed new section is to be inserted because the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has been persuaded, by political pressure, not to back the Commissioner of Taxation in enforcing the existing tax laws as they should apply to government securities. Earlier this year the Taxation Commissioner publicly affirmed the view that profits arising from the sale or redemption at par of securities issued or acquired at a discount are assessable income. In doing so the Commissioner was simply drawing attention-I underline this-to the existence of existing law and the intention of the Commissioner to enforce that law. The relevant sections of the tax law are section 26AAA, which taxes profits arising from sale of property within 12 months, section 26C, which taxes gains made on the sale of Commonwealth securities that do not bear interest, and paragraph 26 (a) which includes in assessable income profits arising from the sale of property acquired for the purpose of making a profit or from carrying on or carrying out a profit-making undertaking or scheme. Whilst these amendments to the legislation make it clear that these laws will always be applied to the sale or redemption of securities from 30 June 1982 there is present in proposed new section 23J (1) a clause which would make exempt from tax profits made on redemption or sale of any securities acquired at a discount on or before 30 June 1982 other than profits made by traders or dealers and profits to which section 26AAA, section 26C or paragraph 26 (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act apply.

I question proposed new section 23J for a number of reasons to which I now refer. If the Government is to suggest, as it says, that it wishes to deal with the cancer of tax avoidance in the community it needs at least to insist on the law, as it currently exists, strictly applying. Of course, laws such as that contained in paragraph 26 (a) are crucial laws in relation to dealing with the question of tax avoidance. In the particular instance before the House concerning the sale or redemption of securities the Taxation Commissioner clearly has not been applying the law as it currently exists. The obligation on the Government should be to ensure that the law is strictly applied to those people who have been acting on the presupposition that the Government is weak on implementation of existing law at least in some areas.

In this case we have a situation whereby the Government's rapid response to pressure has not been in favour of the Commissioner, that is, the Government has not acted certainly to strengthen the hand of the Commissioner in terms of what has happened at least prior to June 1982. Rather this Government has acted in what it believes to be the interest of small investors. However, in my reading of what occurred it was not so much the small investors who placed pressure on the Government as the people involved in selling securities such as those associated with stock exchanges-sharebrokers and so on. They, in fact, no doubt were themselves under criticism because it turned out that they had been giving advice to small investors and, no doubt, as well to large scale investors that the capital gain involved at the securities point of maturation would not be subject to tax. In my view it is not so much the pressure of small investors that has resulted in this amending legislation but rather the fact that rather larger interests associated with security markets made it very clear to the Treasurer that, at least prior to June 1982, they were not prepared to wear this kind of legislation.

I just draw several conclusions from what has happened in this case. Firstly, one has to ask the question, given that the Government has needed to bring in this amending legislation, how strong its commitment will be in this area. I guess that one has to assume that seeing the Government has gone to the trouble of introducing the amendment there will be at least a greater degree of seriousness about the application of tax on capital gains and securities than there has been at least in the past. Secondly, I think the proposed new section is of some interest in terms of the matter raised by the honourable member for Macarthur, that is, the principle of retrospectivity. The Treasurer has indicated that he is prepared to legislate retrospectively to outlaw schemes which are clearly designed to avoid tax, such as bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. He has argued that if it is necessary to legislate to cover such schemes he is prepared to do so. But here we have a case in which legislation is on the books, that is, the law has existed, but it has, in fact, not been enforced. The Treasurer has now clearly indicated that he is prepared to legislate retrospectively to ensure that people do not pay tax which they are required to pay or which they should have paid under existing legislation.

I do not want to go on about this very much longer. What we have is a case where people were really required quite clearly under the Act to pay certain tax . That has been the case; that has been the law. We have, in effect, the Treasurer legislating retrospectively to relieve people of that quite clear legal obligation. Of course, it can be argued, and is argued by the Government, that people were not aware of their obligation. I guess that the Opposition, in not opposing this amendment, has had to take that into account. One might ask the question: Was it not the responsibility of the Government to ensure that people acquiring property-in this case bonds and securities-were made aware of what their commitments were in terms of the law particularly in relation to tax? I think this illustrates the fact that a double morality has been operating in terms of the Government. There has been a morality which operates in terms of the interests of those who have capital, those who have been looked after by this Government; there is another morality where the Government suggests that all the problems of this country go back to the selfishness and the avarice of ordinary wage and salary earners constantly seeking, so the Government would argue, greater and greater wage claims.

If the Government is interested at all in trying to get some understanding in terms of the trade union movement it will have to develop a very different record in relation to its preparedness to ensure that people with capital pay their fair share of tax. I think that in a small way clause 5 of this Bill illustrates the flexibility at least, of the Government in that respect. Admittedly, it has got to the point where the Government is now going to enforce taxation in relation to securities. But it has been prepared also to bow to pressure so that that tax will be applied only after June 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to enter into this debate on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 4) very quickly in respect of the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that it was the Government's intention to extend an existing exemption of pensions paid from the Federal Republic of Germany to Australian residents in compensation for Nazi persecution. The Opposition welcomes extension to that provision. My concern in this debate is to point out that anomaly which exists in this debate in respect of a very limited group of Australian citizens. I understand the basis for this section being placed in the Income Tax Assessment Act in the first place was the international agreement whereby victims of Nazi persecution who were receiving compensation from the Federal Republic of Germany received those payments by way of compensation and were, therefore, exempt from the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Clearly, I suspect that one of the reasons for that was that it was not possible for the Federal Government of Germany to make lump sum payments as restitution to the victims of Nazi atrocities. That would have obviously bankrupted the Republic.

SPEECH.PARA: For years many of these people have been receiving these sums by way of compensation for hardship and suffering often beyond human contemplation. I have a large number of these people in my electorate, many of them of Jewish origin. What has occurred indicates the anomaly that exists in the intention of this Parliament. Clearly we have a situation in which the Government today is extending this provision. What has happened, in fact, is that people have come to Australia and have settled. They may have come from concentration camps. While they have been working and receiving these additional sums by way of compensation they have been income tax exempt. Many of them, often as a result of the hardships which they have suffered, find that they are unable to continue work and have to seek the social service entitlements. That is where the anomaly arises. Whilst income by way of compensation is exempt for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) takes it into account in assessing the entitlements to social service benefits.

I believe it is time that anomaly, which does in a small number of cases cause very practical hardship, should be closely examined by the Government. It seems to me to be clearly absurd to say that a payment is made which ought to be, for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act, exempt because it is seen as compensation. That is the view of the Treasurer. While a person is working and receives the compensation it is exempt but when that person has to cease work and rely on a social service entitlement it affects fringe benefits. It does not matter, in the case of an old age pensioner, whether a pensioner is over 70 years of age. It still affects fringe benefits.

In my electorate there is a number of cases. I have taken up this matter as has Senator Missen in the Senate. We have exchanged correspondence and opinions which we have received from the Department of Social Security. This matter is clearly an anomaly which is working an injustice and which ought to be rectified because we are dealing with a special group of people in our community. They are a declining group. Because of their age, they are not an expanding group. I can understand the Minister for Social Security saying: 'Given the tightening economic circumstances, I do not want to make a grant which is obviously going to go to a group that is going to enlarge'. It seems to me-there is certainly a number of cases which I and Senator Missen from Victoria have received-that real hardship is being effected on individual citizens because they are now in receipt of these compensation payments.

I believe that if it is the view of this House and it is the view of the Treasurer that these payments ought to be exempt for the purposes of income tax, equally, they ought to be exempt by the Minister for Social Security when he is considering the entitlements that these elderly citizens receive. I commend that view to the Treasurer and to the Government. I hope that, between the passage of this legislation in this House and its consideration in the Senate, the Minister for Social Security will use the occasion to bring his viewpoint into line with the viewpoint of the Treasurer. It is an anomaly. It is working an injustice in a number of cases and those injustices ought to be rectified. I draw that matter to the attention of the Treasurer, the attention of the Minister for Social Security and to the attention of the Government in the hope that on this occasion we can rectify what is clearly the expressed intention and view of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980, the then Minister for Social Security who is now the Minister, Senator Chaney, reiterated the previous advice that Frank Stewart had received but indicated that the matter was under review by his Department and by the Government. Another item to which I address myself is the proposal in this Bill to grant tax deductibility to organisations that collect funds for overseas disasters. I also address my remarks tonight to the matter of tax evasion which has been canvassed at length in this Parliament today. The only remarks I make on the general matter of tax evasion is that it is ironic that under this Government the only real growth industry has been the tax evasion industry. We have had some rather remarkable people lobbying Government members of parliament in recent weeks about the retrospectivity laws that the Government intends to introduce. One such remarkable person is Mrs Millie Phillips, that well-known exploiter of mining proposals and the old aged in Australia. She saw fit today to take sufficient umbrage with the Government's approach to send a telegram to all Government members telling them that the party she had supported all her life was now starting to lose her favour because it was at last starting to wake up to tax 'avoision'-I should say, tax avoidance. I suppose I have fallen into the trap of amalgamating the two words as other speakers in this Parliament have today.

Frankly, I do not find all that much difference between tax evasion and tax avoidance. As a person who has spent all his working life paying pay-as-you-earn tax, I think there is no real way that those people who pay pay-as-you-earn tax can get involved in either of those types of tax manipulations. I think that the sooner tax evasion and avoidance are stamped out the better it will be for the great bulk of Australians who are contributing to the cost of running this country.

In the main I address my remarks tonight to what strikes me as some peculiar things that are occuring in the Australian Taxation Office in Sydney in particular as they affect the migrant community in my electorate. In the last few weeks, some considerable space has been given in the media to the concept of discounting of group certificates. I must say that matter was foreign to me until last week when a number of people from the migrant community in my electorate brought it to my attention. They brought to my attention the iniquity that is worked on a number of people by the practice of group certificate discounting. One of the greatest perpetrators of this scheme in Sydney is a Mr Dekanic of a company called Dekanic Accountancy Pty Ltd of 305 King Street, Newtown. Mr Dekanic is not new to this area. In fact, this has been a matter of scandal in the Australian Taxation Office in Sydney and the migrant community of Sydney for some three years. It is a matter that has been known to the bureaucracy for some time. It is common knowledge in tax circles and in the migrant community. The Commissioner of Taxation decided to take action only after the matter was revealed in the media and the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Whelan, took action in the New South Wales Parliament yesterday.

It is important for members of this Parliament, who are responsible for the oversight of the tax laws, to understand what Mr Dekanic does. He preys on new migrants to Australia and a number of people in this country who are still illegal immigrants and who have little knowledge of English or the Australian bureaucracy. The people he preys upon are mainly those from the Pacific Islands of Samoa, Tonga and Fiji and members of the Yugoslav community in Sydney. The most despicable part of his operation is that to these people he asserts that he is an official government representative. I suppose that to the extent that he is a registered tax agent he can say that he has some fifth or sixth hand connection with the Australian Government but he asserts to these people that he is the Government's representative. That is abhorrent to me as a member of the Australian Parliament who represents most of these people.

This gentlemen asks people to sign a standard Form S taxation return. That form has been pre-typed. He has hundreds of these forms typed and gets people to sign them. Not only do they sign that form in a number of places but also they sign an assignment form. I will go further into what that assignment form does in a few moments. It is interesting that the Taxation Office has not got on to the fraud that has been perpetrated before now. This gentlemen presents thousands of Form S taxation returns to the Australian Taxation Office in Sydney every year. It strikes me that the fact that all these forms are the same and are all rote typed in his office should have woken people to the fact that something crooked is going on.

This man, in my view, is one of the worst thieves in the area adjacent to my electorate. He preys on people who do not know their rights. On the Form S taxation returns he alleges that all these people are members of the Australian Workers Union. They are not but he claims a taxation deduction for them. He provides the forms and asks people to sign them. All the details are typed on a typewriter in his office. If the taxation authorities get the police to check the typewriter they will know that that is so. He asserts that these people have all made donations to the Salvation Army, the Red Cross, the Police Boys Club and the Smith Family. It is ironic that all these institutions are listed in the same order on thousands of forms. It is most improbable that all those new migrants and illegal immigrants would have donated to those four charities in one year. However, that improbability has not struck the people in the Taxation Office in Sydney. They have done nothing about the matter until now.

Mr Dekanic then asks people to assign to him their tax rebate cheques. People sign a simple form that allows him to place their cheques from the Taxation Office into his Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Ltd account. After they have signed all these forms he tells them that he is the official Government agent, that he has fixed everything up for them with the Government and they do not need to wait for three or four months to get their refunds. He opens his drawer and gives them $100 or $200 cash. What these people forgo are tax refunds of hundreds of dollars to which they are entitled. In the New South Wales Parliament yesterday Mr Whelan presented a statutory declaration from one of his and my constituents that showed that Mr Dekanic had turned over to him a tax refund cheque worth $385 for which he paid the taxpayer $250. He received $135. That is not bad for filling in a standard Form S tax return. Most reputable accountants and tax agents would ask for $25 or $30. Mr Dekanic has admitted in the Sydney Press that this happens. He sees nothing wrong with it. Obviously the Taxation Office in New South Wales saw nothing wrong with it. It has only now started to do something about it.

The practice of discounting group certificates at present is legal. It strikes me that the one thing that should not be legal is this sort of practice. It is disgusting. The law should be amended to make it illegal for a taxpayer to assign his rebate cheque to a tax agent or his agent. The Government should do something about it urgently. This man is involved not only in these legal but quasi-illegal activities, but also in the illegal activity of laundering stolen group certificates. The Taxation Office has had at least one example of a group certificate being presented by this man on behalf of an alleged client and a genuine duplicate group certificate being presented later to the Taxation Office on behalf of a client who had a statutory declaration to say that he had lost his group certificate or had it stolen. How does this man manage to collect these things? Obviously, there are forgeries of signatures. This practice must be stopped. It is theft and corruption practised against people who are least able to help themselves.

One must ask oneself why nothing has been done. How could this iniquitous process go on for three years with nothing being done? Even if the practice is legal, why has the man not had his licence as a tax agent revoked? The legislation as it exists now would allow that to occur. Nothing has been done. This begs the question that the man has been protected somewhere along the line. As the investigation being conducted into the matter now is by extremely junior officers in the Department who are not as competent as others in their jobs, it seems that a great cover-up is about to be perpetrated on the theft by this man from migrants whom I represent in the Parliament and from other people who do not know their rights under the Australian taxation laws. To my mind, the most damning evidence against this man is his statement to the Sydney Press yesterday . Mr Dekanic, the man who has thieved from these migrants, said:
Why don't they-
He means the Government-
legislate what we-
That is, tax agents-
should do? That is the same as bottom-of-the-harbour schemes: They just make a fuss to cover up their own laziness.

I would like to know tonight whose laziness is being covered up. Who are the corrupt people in this operation? Why has this man not had his tax agent's licence revoked? Why has he not been prosecuted? Why is he allowed to continue to defraud thousands of my constituents and people in the migrant community in Sydney? Week in week out he thieves from these people while he purports to be the official representative of the Australian Government. To my mind it is time that the Taxation Office gave some explanation of why nothing has been done. This is one of the worst frauds perpetrated against people who do not know their own rights that I have seen in the years I have been in the Parliament. It needs to be cleared up. The Government needs to ensure that it cannot occur again by changing the law so that tax agents cannot have assigned to them the tax refund cheques of unwitting taxpayers. To take from the mouths of people who are on low incomes what is justly theirs from the Australian Government is, as the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs said, a heinous crime. It is a crime that the Taxation Office has allowed to occur. For at least three years it has known that it has gone on. Something has to be done. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh), who is at the table tonight, should bring this matter to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Government should take action quick smart. In the next few weeks in this Parliament I would like to hear an explanation of how this has occurred. I will be raising this matter in the adjournment debate and during Question Time with the Treasurer to find out what has happened with this investigation and why this man is still allowed to practise as a tax agent.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Budget was interrupted last night I was about to deal with the causes of inflation. I point out, as I have done previously, that our level of inflation is higher than that of any of our trading partners and is rising, despite the promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1975, 1977 and 1980 that he would bring it down. On the contrary, it is going up. I will outline just a few of the many causes of inflation in this country-causes which the Government does not wish to acknowledge. They include: The increases in petrol prices; that is, the world parity pricing system which the Government introduced and the increase of 1c a litre in this Budget; the increases in health charges in this and previous Budgets; and high interest rates which, of course, affect everything. Interest rates at these levels affect local government rates because local governments have to borrow at very much higher rates. They affect electricity charges for the generation of electricity by the State electricity commissions and the county councils which have to raise their funds on a very much higher interest rate market. They affect telephone charges and prices of all goods. A manufacturer or businessman providing a service and working on an overdraft, with interest rates rising by 3 per cent, has two alternatives: To go broke or to increase his prices. It is as simple as that. Accordingly, that has quite an impact. One could go on and on about the causes of inflation, particularly because this Government generates inflation simply by the policies it follows.

SPEECH.PARA: I also make the point that this is a give and take Budget. Revenue from taxes comprises over 25 per cent of the gross domestic product in this year's Budget. This is approximately the same figure as in last year's Budget which had the highest figure for tax collections of any year to that date. In other words, there has been no reduction whatsoever in the level of taxes being collected. For this reason I submit that the Budget is a fraud in that it gives benefits with one hand and takes with the other. It takes through increased indirect taxes. Whenever there is an election, it will be a repeat performance of 1977. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Budget gave various benefits, tax reductions in particular, before the election and when the election was over the next Budget took all those tax reductions back. That is the type of political morality of this Government. It set this precedent in 1977. It set the precedent then and it will carry out again. The people should beware and be aware of the intentions of the Government. As I said, the Prime Minister is politically completely dishonest in his approach to these matters. For that reason he will once again perpetuate this confidence trick of giving something before an election and taking it all back after an election, with the result that the people are worse off than they were before. In addition to that, the Prime Minister is quite psychotic in his fear that the Australian Labor Party may refuse to pass the Budget in the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: In the short time available I want to deal with the introduction of the tax of up to $1 on cheques of $5,000. The banks have been screaming. They are rather quiet at the moment. It must be remembered that the Prime Minister himself, with the Nareen Pastoral Co. and this interwoven group of companies including Fraser Properties Pty Ltd, engaged in tax avoidance. TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget is very timely. It recognises the hardship that exists in the community, it is realistic about the recession and it tries to cushion the blow for those who are hardest hit, especially those on fixed incomes, the pensioners and the unemployed. It is a family Budget, and that can be seen by its tax measures, family allowances and housing assistance. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) last night did nothing short of insult our intelligence. He exposed the complete lack of an Australian Labor Party policy in this area. He had a great time insulting people . All he really tried to do was to get into the Clancy column in the National Times, the Quotes of the Week in the Bulletin and Column 8 of the Sydney Morning Herald. He did not say anything of substance.

SPEECH.PARA: What should he have done? He should have given the ALP alternative, what we can expect if ever the ALP gets into government. But he gave no such thing-no policies. His speech was completely void of suggestions. He gave no remedies for unemployment, no ideas on inflation and no solutions to high interest rates, and he revealed no desire to help home buyers. Obviously the ALP does not want to give relief to pensioners; it wants only to see its words in print. The ALP is happier giving insults than finding solutions to economic problems. It is at times like this that I wish the proceedings of Parliament were broadcast in the Northern Territory. The best advantage that I could gain electorally in the Northern Territory would be for the people of the Territory to listen to the sort of tripe that the Leader of the Opposition put over last night.

I turn to some specific measures in this Budget that relate to my electorate. I shall talk first about the funding for the Northern Territory Government. This year the figure for State-type services in the Northern Territory is $731m, representing an increase of 18 per cent. It is the highest commitment ever given and it demonstrates very clearly what the Fraser Government thinks of self- government and the confidence that it has in the future of the Northern Territory. At the same time it is a Budget that recognises our special problems, those that are induced by isolation. It recognises very humanely and compassionately the particular problems of Aboriginal communities throughout the Northern Territory. The grant for State-type services is $5,500 a head. This strong financial support is needed because we have a historical problem. We need to overcome the disadvantages and the past neglect. These issues were all clearly recognised by the memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government. That sets out the continuing financial support which is needed to provide, firstly, for proper transport and communications; secondly, for a soundly based economy; and thirdly, for Aboriginal advancement. Overall the level of funding reflects the growth of population in the Northern Territory at a time when nowhere else in Australia can claim the same sort of growth. It reflects the growth in the Northern Territory economy which can be equalled nowhere else in Australia.

An interesting aspect to note relating to the revenue that has been passed to the Northern Territory Government as compensation is the increase in the uranium royalties. This year they are to be increased by 190 per cent to $3.4m. That is paralleled by the growth of the industry in the Northern Territory. It will continue to increase in importance with the new mines that have come on stream. I refer to Pan-Continental at Jabiluka and, eventually, Koongarra. Uranium royalties will improve as the price of uranium picks up.

What has the ALP to offer in this regard? Its last conference was an absolute sell out. ALP spokesmen right around Australia and in the Northern Territory are saying that under a Labor Government no new mines will open in the Northern Territory. Does that offer any form of security or assistance to Territorians? Does it offer any form of advancement to the Aboriginals who will gain from the mining royalties that will eventuate from our policies? The spokesmen are completely and utterly bereft in their support for Northern Territory industry. They want to pull the rug from underneath the uranium industry of the Northern Territory. At least this Commonwealth Government recognises the industry's importance and sticks with it.

I turn to the area of taxation. In my electorate 39,000 taxpayers will benefit from this Budget. I am pleased and happy to stand up to say that. In particular, it will help over 3,000 taxpayers who recently crept into the 46 per cent tax bracket. The tax relief was necessary and welcomed by many families in the Northern Territory, given the high cost of living, the high rents and housing costs and the expensive transport costs. The spouse rebate was an issue of concern. I had many electoral representations over this matter. We should not penalise one income families. This year, of course, the increase of $200 in the rebate moves towards eliminating the anomaly involved. Zone allowances in the Northern Territory are important to our taxpayers. They remove some of the inequities but unfortunately they were not increased this year along with the other tax advantages, and that is a disappointment.

I welcome particularly the moves to end the double taxation on dividends. On the broad scene, currently 2 per cent of domestic savings in Australia are invested through stock exchanges. Traditionally they have not been lucrative enough for the small investor and the taxation aspect previously was obviously abused. The move this year should provide encouragement for the small investor to invest. The increases in the family allowances will affect over 20,000 families in my electorate. They represent a sensible step in line with cost of living adjustments. The family income supplement deserves credit because it is aimed at low income earners with children, those who need compassion and care. The payment of $10 is not insignificant to those people and it will provide real assistance over and above income and family allowances. It is an innovative benefit.

There is sense in many other areas of the welfare budget. I refer to the pension increases. This year 7,600 pensioners in my electorate will benefit. Their tax systems will be adjusted. The tax threshold has been increased to $4, 595. That ensures that pensioners will not be taxed despite all the fear- mongering that was put around in the year by the Opposition. It protects the small savings of pensioners this year. Those who have a liberalised income will be able to benefit, to take real advantage. The pensioner rebate is a new idea that ensures that many of those in this area, with the extra $250, now have extra advantages. The permissible savings have been increased; the tests for fringe benefits have been eased.

I agree with the measures for pensioners but I appreciate that they will not solve all the problems of pensioners, particularly those who live in high cost areas in the Territory. They do not get zone allowances except on their small additional incomes; they do not get district allowances as do most wage earners. Therefore, I think that the rebate should be tied to the taxation rebate system for zone allowances and increased proportionately. The interest rate relief this year has done more to promote home ownership under this Government than any other measures in this Budget, and it is in addition to the policies that were announced in March. It is not just up to the Commonwealth to look at this area. I believe that the State and local governments also should act more deliberately in the area of housing. The Northern Territory Government has given an excellent example with its concessional interest based home loan scheme and the States would do well to follow this example. State and local governments can also assist in the housing arena by keeping down costs for home buyers and builders in the areas of stamp duty, transfer costs on land purchases and a whole range of similar areas. The March housing policy was aimed at first home buyers and was a welcome new policy. This year the Budget is aimed at all home buyers with an interest problem. The problem in the Northern Territory is not with people just buying their first home. Many of them have come in because of development reasons from interstate and may not be buying their first home; it may be a second or a later home. Yet they have difficulties because the cost of an average three-bedroom home is about $80,000. So the benefits that they will attract this year, if they qualify for a loan of $60,000, will be sensible and fair. If they have taken out a loan of $50,000 at 14 per cent they will qualify for over $14 per week in rebate. It will also provide an additional advantage to the Northern Territory housing industry. This is important in Darwin where a satellite suburb at Palmerston is about to take off. The rebate will be of tremendous advantage there.

The area of transport is always a contentious issue for the Northern Territory because of its geographical location, its long distances and the peculiar problems that it must face. We must continue to be able to provide proper road, rail, shipping and aerodrome networks. This Budget moves in that direction because it addresses all four areas in the Northern Territory. The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program is innovative and courageous. It is practical and tangible and it will mean a lot more than all the flag waving, band playing celebrations that may happen in other places. It is important for the Northern Territory where road transport is vital. The major highways in the Territory badly need upgrading. It is also important to improve many approaches, previously Northern Territory highways, which are locked in on their approach routes interstate. Substantial stretches of the adjoining highways in Western Australian and Queensland are not sealed and very little of the road from Port Augusta to the Northern Territory border is sealed. The trips are often hazardous and difficult. Under this program these roads will be sealed on an integrated bitumen road network.

The Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) has already set out the specific advantages of these upgrading programs in all areas. Additionally, it will facilitate travel for tourist purposes, enable local government to upgrade roads and expand the opportunities for commerce, assist in the development of our natural resources and mean a more efficient freight service to many areas. There are many indirect social benefits, such as reducing the road toll, savings in fuel consumption and providing employment. I agree with the establishment of a trust account for the levy money so that it will not be caught up. The money has been specially designated, it has been put aside and it is easy to see where the benefits will go; unlike what Wran has done in New South Wales in imposing a levy of 5c because the State is broke. He has had to put it into the coffers, not in the roads. The levy will benefit the Northern Territory. If the levy had been imposed last year on the consumption rates it would have yielded to Treasury about $1m, but the program announced by the Minister for the coming financial year shows that the Northern Territory stands to get $4.6m from the bicentennial roads program in addition to the program already agreed to.

Shipping coastal subsidies have been maintained and increased and this will keep freight costs down. The Alice Springs to Darwin railway commitment has been reinforced with over $3m provided to continue the survey work. I only hope that the problems associated with Aboriginal sites can be resolved in the forthcoming year so that construction can start and deadlines can be met. Judging from past performance on the Tarcoola to Alice Springs railway this will be possible. The upgrading of the Gove Airport is a welcome announcement. Jets will be able to land with a greater frequency. This will greatly assist a much isolated community. I note that Darwin is listed on the civil works program but did not specifically gain funding this year for its new domestic terminal program. That certainly needs urgent action. The work is badly needed and it must be done at a time when the defence review is going on with all defence requirements in the Top End.

I am disturbed about the Customs duty excise on diesel because it will have an impact on the tourist arena. It is necessary that those isolated communities which are fuelling their own power should be able to enjoy concessions from that rebate. I hope they will be put in place and agreed at an early date. In the communications area it is pleasing to note the extension of the high frequency inland radio service. This will benefit pastoral and Aboriginal communities. It is part of a program to upgrade communications in remote areas. The remote area television program is to be completed this year. When that is linked also with the progress for the domestic satellite, I believe and I can say quite confidently we will see an interesting and a positive revolution in Aboriginal communities between 1986 and 1990 when television will be beamed in to all of those communities and they will be able to upgrade their general education and take advantage of many things in our community.

The Dix report on the Australian Broadcasting Commission highlighted the neglected areas in the past in the ABC area. I am hopeful that at a very early time we will be able to rectify the imbalance that comes through many of the ABC areas. The pastoral industry will be relieved of the debt that has been hanging over its head with the brucellosis and tuberculosis campaign. That was an unfair burden on cattlemen. The eradication is always difficult and costly in the Territory because of lack of fences and other problems, but the uncertainty in the meat industry is certainly something we did not need at that time. If the debt had had to be met it would have caused major difficulties. Our rural industries are tight enough with droughts in southern areas and high costs in remote areas. They do not want things like that to make it more difficult.

Aboriginal affairs always continue to be a major concern in my electorate. Approximately a quarter of the population lives in Aboriginal communities and relates to Aboriginal communities. It is very pleasing to note that this Budget continues to be a major concern of this Government. Aboriginal advancement programs total $163.8m which is an increase of 12.4 per cent. The Aboriginal Development Commission which has undertaken many great and innovative programs throughout the Territory has got $59m. Additional expenditures affect many Aboriginal communities in the fields of health, education, employment and social security. The Minister has announced major allocations in all of these areas for the Territory. In addition community management programs get a lot of extra money to complete the work on sewerage and on power in a number of communities. The Minister has also given priority to alcohol rehabilitation which affects so many people in those communities.

One area in the Aboriginal arena that I would like to highlight is that Aboriginal communities currently have to deal with at least 16 agencies to gain their financial funding. I think this is confusing and far too bureaucratic. There needs to be a reduction in the number of agencies-but not the programs and or the financing-to simplify the liaison and the challenge. Any community would be bewildered if it had to deal with 16 different funding channels. This problem is compounded in Aboriginal communities. I would like to see the funds in the administrative programs redirected to far more constructive programs. This Budget is a great Budget for the Northern Territory. It has some problems but overall it is also a very great Budget for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to outline some of the difficulties being expeienced by small business owners at the Ginninderra Village complex, an historic and unique tourist attraction on the outskirts of Canberra. Problems have arisen because the new owner of the premises has raised tenants' rents by more than 300 per cent. Naturally, the small businesses involved oppose such massive increases and have attempted to put their case for a fairer deal. Negotiations with the new owners proved unsatisfactory and no progress was made. Discussions with the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) also failed to achieve a fairer deal for the tenants. Despite repeated attempts to resolve the situation, the tenants feel cheated and disappointed by the Minister's apparent lack of concern for their predicament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister did ask the Department of the Capital Territory to arrange for an arbiter to determine fair rents earlier this year. Despite the fact that it could reasonably be assumed that the tenants were significant parties in this dispute, the tenants were not consulted during the arbitration procedure which was carried out by a valuer in conjunction with the Department and the new owner . The result of the so-called arbitration was rent increases of more than 300 per cent. No reasons were given nor were there any comparisons with other similar types of property.

To add insult to injury tenants were then presented with a bill for $641, half the cost of the arbitration, even though at no stage were they given the opportunity to put their case. Understandably, the tenants are very angry. It appears that the Government is condoning profiteering from public land. In this case the land rent paid by the owner each year is $3,200. This allows the owner to receive $14,000 per annum from current rent paid by tenants and at least $35, 000 per year if the massive rental increases are forced on the tenants. The situation of these tenants highlights the need for an effective business leases tribunal. I hope the Minister for the Capital Territory will assure us very soon that we will fully investigate this problem and will explain to us how the business leases tribunal would operate. He has discussed the possibility of establishing this tribunal for years and we still see no evidence that such a tribunal is to be established.

I have spoken on many previous occasions about the difficulties of small business people in relation to the major shopping centres in Canberra, most of which are controlled by Lend Lease Corporation Ltd. All of these cases highlight the problems that small business people face when natural justice is denied to them and no independent avenues of appeal are available. A spokesperson for the Ginninderra Village traders summed up the situation well by stating:

The Government talks a lot about small business, but when it comes to the crunch it obviously doesn't give a damn. It has allowed massive rent increases which not only force the businesses out of operation but deny more than 200 craftspeople-including some from Tasmania--

It shows the Liberal Party doesn't care about the people it claims to represent -the ordinary small business person. If it won't do anything to help them in the ACT where it has total control what hope do Australians in other places have?

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that concerns me is that I now have in my hands proof that a health fund, Medibank, which is losing money in nearly every State of Australia, is offering to people who work for certain banks or companies special deals that are not available to the general public. I regard this as discriminatory and also as contravening the report in the Australian Financial Review of 30 December 1981 that the Government had warned health funds about discounting. Medibank stated that all waiting periods will be waived if people join Medibank-even the 12-month qualifying period for major dental work-that the known expense rule will not be applied; and that the 9-month obstetrics rule will not be applied.

SPEECH.PARA: When I heard the wonderful news that my wife is to have a baby next month- exactly a month away today-I discovered that I was not registered in the highest scale in my health fund. That was my bad luck. But if I were working for the Commercial Banking Company of Sydney I could wait until my wife was 8 3/4 months pregnant, join Medibank, have the best hospital accommodation, receive first class medical treatment, and after the baby is born leave the fund. No wonder this health fund is in so much trouble. No wonder its management expenses are so high. No wonder it is losing so much money in so many States of Australia. Why should the staff of this bank be given any special treatment over the ordinary citizens of Australia?
