SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity tonight to draw the attention of the House to what I consider to be a harsh decision of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in relation to a constituent of mine, Mr Alan Ashmore. As a Vietnam veteran in receipt of a disability pension, Mr Ashmore has had nearly two years of frustrating correspondence with the Department in relation to claims for medical costs with, I regret to say, the Department and, finally, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) declining to make any reimbursement to Mr Ashmore. Honourable members will be aware that a number or research studies have been made both here and in the United States of America which have indicated a possible link between illnesses suffered by Vietnam war veterans and the war in Vietnam. A number of Australian war veterans, of whom Mr Ashmore is one, have been considerably worried about any possible link with their own disabilities and their exposure to toxic chemicals in Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past three years Vietnam veterans have been blocked by the Federal Government at every attempt to obtain information about any exposure of Vietnam veterans to harmful quantities of toxic herbicides. As the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has stated, veterans have a right to all the available information on the use of toxic chemicals in Vietnam as well as a right to an expert assessment of the effects of their exposure to them. The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment is at present inquiring into the possible effects of the exposure of toxic chemicals on Vietnam veterans and is expecting to present its report shortly. However, the Association is calling for a royal commission and I support such a call because I agree with the Association that this is the only way of ensuring an independent investigation of the matters.

Having set the background to Mr Ashmore's dispute with the Department of Veterans' Affairs I will now deal with the details of his case. Mr Ashmore, having decided with his wife that they would like to commence a family also decided that it would be wise for him to undergo sperm tests to uncover any possible abnormalities in view of the possible link between birth defects and chemical poisoning. This view was also supported by their medical practitioner. Mr and Mrs Ashmore were also advised by their local practitioner that Mrs Ashmore's pregnancy should be monitored in case of possible abnormalities.

Despite the fact that the tests would not have been necessary had Mr Ashmore not served in Vietnam, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs refused to accept any liability on behalf of the Government and sheltered behind the claim that no legislative provisions existed to reimburse Mr and Mrs Ashmore for their medical costs. The rejection of Mr Ashmore's second claim was, in my view, even more inequitable than the rejection of the first claim. Mr Ashmore suffers from a severe form of dermatitis, called neurodermatitis, which is a skin disorder which causes him considerable discomfort. Because of the severity of the condition Mr Ashmore's local repatriation doctor referred him to a skin specialist. The subsequent treatment was only marginally effective and so the repatriation doctor finally referred him to a naturopath. The Department of Veterans' Affairs, supported subsequently by the Minister, declined to reimburse Mr Ashmore for the $200 cost of his treatment by the naturopath.

I find the grounds for the decision of the Department that its policy is to pay for treatment only by recognised and established ancillary medical services and that those services do not include naturopathic services to be very bad grounds. I understand that the Department has been guided in its decisions by the views of the Australian Medical Association which does not encourage the use of alternative forms of therapy. I do not accept, nor would many people in the community, that the view of the AMA represents a consensus opinion of the medical profession as to what treatment is worth while. Many people in the community benefit from what is often described as unconventional forms of medical treatment. I question the impartiality of the AMA in such matters.

The AMA is one of the most conservative professional bodies in our community whose closed shop practices appear to be designed wholly to protect the remuneration of their members rather than encourage the practice of medicine for the benefit of sick people. The result of the refusal by the Minister to even consider changing the policy of his Department in relation to alternative medicine sources means that Mr Ashmore will no doubt have to resort to the considerably more expensive treatment of a skin specialist, at the expense of the taxpayer.

Mr Ashmore has asked me to pursue this matter on his behalf and although I have appealed to the Minister he has not accepted the grounds of my appeal. My last resort is to bring the circumstances of Mr Ashmore's case to the attention of the House. The legacy of the Vietnam war will linger with us for many years to come but the Minister and his Department should at least introduce policies which show that the Government has some sympathy with those Vietnam veterans who are presently suffering from medical complaints which they contracted during the war. At the moment Vietnam veterans are justifiably feeling that they are being neglected and ignored by a government which has no understanding of their problems and can offer them no hope for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw the attention of the House to the drought that is affecting New South Wales in particular and of course my electorate along with the neighbouring electorate of Eden-Monaro and many others . This matter was raised in this House at Question Time yesterday and on a previous occasion. On both those occasions comment was made about the role of the New South Wales Government in providing assistance. There is no doubt that the New South Wales Government has falsely alleged that there has been a lack of support by the Federal Government in endeavours to provide relief to those farmers who are drought affected. In this context I think it is worth while pointing out exactly what the facts are about the Federal Government's assistance to drought relief in this nation. The last major drought that affected New South Wales was regrettably only a couple of years ago. In the 1980 -81 financial year the Federal Government demonstrated, with money, the extent of its support for the farmers of that State when conditions had become seriously adverse. It is against the background of that demonstration of support that the statements made by the New South Wales Government and the New South Wales Minister responsible are utterly disgraceful. They are a further attempt to play politics with the livelihoods of the farmers of that State who are suffering severely as a result of their second major drought in three seasons.
—Typical of that Government.

When there is trouble in New South Wales, when there is trouble in any State in the rural communities, it is the Federal Government that provides the real relief. In other words in 1980-81, when there was a drought in New South Wales which severely affected the farmers in that State, the Federal Government, through its specific drought assistance, provided almost two-thirds of the total help to that State. The New South Wales Government knows that. It knows that those arrangements persist to this day. Yet State Government Ministers are pretending, falsely and maliciously to the farmers of New South Wales, that they are unable to provide adequate assistance because the Federal Government is not providing adequate funding. Have honourable members ever heard such deceptive bunkum?

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the interesting thing is that not only is the system which existed in 1980-81 persisting-that is that once the States reach a moderate target level the Federal Government provides $3 for every $1 that is provided by the States- but also in addition to that the Federal Government has ensured that the States will not run out of money for this purpose this year and has provided an advance payment of $10m. I am assured by farming organisations that the rate of application for relief at the moment is so slow that there is no way this $10m will be used up in the near future. In effect the Federal Government is meeting the great bulk of the cost even before the minimum level required to be paid by the State, before Federal assistance is triggered in normal terms, has been met. The State Government is not meeting its responsibilities to the farmers of New South Wales in this drought. The State Government has deceptively misled the farmers to suggest that the Federal Government is not providing assistance. As is usual we will provide the bulk of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a number of years I was a member of a State legislature and every six months the question of the need for a second airport for Sydney was raised. Unfortunately now that I am a member of this House, I find that the question of a second airport seems to be a re-submit at six monthly intervals also. This issue is far too serious to be just brought before the House or trailed out by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) every six months . It is important that Sydney obtain a second airport and it is essential that the Government, at this stage, announce the site for it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appalling that so many people in the outer areas of Sydney, so many young couples who are buying homes, have their properties at risk because some large site must be set aside for a second airport. The danger to the heavily populated residential areas of Sydney is enormous. We have aircraft flying over day and night on the north-south flight path. It is a complete danger to people living underneath the flight path; it is a danger to children in schools; it is a danger to hospitals and other institutions. Yet this Government will do nothing about the second airport for Sydney. It is a matter not of noise, not of pollution; it is a matter of danger and public safety. After all, that is surely one of the reasons why we are all in this House-to legislate in the interest of public safety and public health. Public safety is in jeopardy while we have a major airport located in the middle of the largest city in this country.

I well remember the Parramatta by-election in July 1973 and the furore that the suggestion of an airport at Galston created. I believe that has frightened subsequent governments and led them to play act with this issue of a second airport in Sydney. Thousands of people are involved. Thousands of jobs are involved. The location of the airport must be announced now-not put off for another year-because it is a long term project. There is a need for service corridors. There is a need for rail services to be provided and for roads to be built. All of these services will be paid for by the Commonwealth Government. Not one penny of State money will go into the airport yet the Minister in the House and in the newspapers has made statements the there must be an agreement with the State Government. This is absolute rubbish. The New South Wales Government said this when it withdrew from the Major Airport Needs of Sydney study. It said that the whole issue was in the hands of the Commonwealth Government and the Commonwealth Government had to take the odium and the responsibility for deciding the site for Sydney's second airport. The whole thing has become a charade. It is hurting tourism in this nation. However, we cannot expect much from this Government because this is the insensitive Government that introduced the $20 departure tax. Nevertheless, it is the issue of public safety that I wish to raise tonight.

I was a member of another parliament in February 1980 when the plane to Temora crashed. There were 12 passengers killed. Many of us thought that the member for Temora in the State House was a passenger. The accident occurred on a Thursday night after the House rose. It was a tragedy. We were only thankful that the member had missed that plane. The indifference of this Government, the procrastinating nature of the Government and the lack of real concern and real planning are threats to country people. The Government regards planning as a dirty word. Yet it is country people who are suffering. It was country people returning to the bush with their families who were killed in that tragic plane crash when the Beech Super King crashed at Sydney Airport.

As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) said, had we had an airport with a skirt around the runway there would have been ample room for that plane having difficulty taking off to land. It could not land; it hit the rocks and all the passengers and all the crew were killed. This is the reality of Sydney's airport. It is too small. Yet the Minister is flying a kite about a stubby runway, another runway out into Botany Bay. All the expense is, of course , in dredging the bay. I draw this matter to the attention of the House because I believe it is a matter of public safety that this Government must grapple with . Australia is becoming a farce overseas. Tourists are stranded because of the curfew at Sydney Airport. Yet a stubby runway at Sydney Airport would bring more flights not only over my electorate but also over the electorate of Barton and the suburbs of Hunters Hill, Artarmon and the North Shore-all of these suburbs represented by Government members. I think that the House and the nation will eventually condemn this Government for its inaction on the matter of a second airport in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before a Budget is presented there are many allegations about what is to be in the Budget. There is a lot of so-called informed comment from people, particularly in the Press gallery, who regard themselves as experts in this area. I point out that among the many forecasts that were made before this Budget there was one that lump sum superannuation benefits were to be taxed in some way by the Government. What I wish to do tonight is simply to dramatise to the House and to those people who made these allegations that that was total nonsense. Lump sum superannuation benefits have not been changed in any way in the Federal Budget. I think the people who spread that kind of rumour should be aware of that. The allegations that there would be changes in the taxation treatment of lump sum superannuation benefits have, in fact, for the second time in a row been proved false in this Budget. I stressed some time ago that the Budget would not make any such changes. Of course, it did not set a limit-despite these politically inspired rumours, I suggest-on the level of superannuation benefit that may be paid in the form of a lump sum.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will remember that during the 1980 election campaign the Government indicated that it had no intention of altering the present taxation arrangements for lump sum superannuation benefits. Despite those assurances there have been continual rumours-politically inspired-that there would be a change. At that time a commitment was made that the Government would not change these rules during the life of the present Parliament. This remains the situation. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in fact asserted this only a little while ago. Yet we found many people prepared to go into print saying that there would be such changes. I recognise that some administrative arrangements have been changed for some small business superannuation funds which were being used for tax avoidance reasons. As the House knows, no government has been more assiduous than this Government in closing such loopholes. As a result the Commissioner of Taxation altered the arrangements to overcome the unintended exploitation of the superannuation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act relating to small business superannuation funds. These arrangements became operational from 1 July this year. Details were announced last May.

It must be restated that not only were there no changes to lump sum superannuation tax treatment in the last Budget but also there will be no change in the taxation treatment of lump sum superannuation, at least during the term of the current Parliament. I do not know how many more times that has to be said before honourable members opposite and members of the Press corps gallery will act on this matter responsibly so that they do not terrorise some people into early retirement. I point out that some people were so unnerved by these false rumours that they left their employment before they should have, so diminishing the amount of benefit they would get on retirement. This was because of these pre-Budget rumours. It seems to me to be most unfortunate that people who spread this sort of rumour for political purposes are unaware of the real consequences they have on people approaching retirement who may well-

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not care.

—As my honourable friend said, they do not care about the people who are approaching retirement and who, in fact, have made decisions which have cost them money simply because the honourable members opposite found it politically useful to terrorise such people. I hope that the people of Australia recognise that the undertaking given that there would be no change in the tax treatment of lump sum superannuation payments during the life of the present Parliament will, in fact, be maintained by this Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Can he say whether there are any moves by banks to introduce a charge for each transaction conducted by a customer; if so, (a) what will be the nature of charges and (b) are building societies also contemplating such a move.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The trading banks at present apply a range of charges and fees in respect of customers' transactions, although certain customers, for example non-profit organisations, are generally exempt. The most common fees and charges are cheque account-keeping fees related to the number of debit and credit items over a specified period, usually a quarter. Rebates of the fees are normally allowed when the balance of the account does not fall below a specified minimum. Charges are also levied by banks on other transactions including, for example, those involving overseas payments. Such charges are designed to recoup, in part or in full, the cost to the bank of providing the relevant service to the customer. The form and structure of the various charges differ between banks.
There are no charges on deposits to and withdrawals from savings banks' customers' accounts (except where an additional service is provided, such as issue of a bank cheque).
The detail of the above charges is subject to regular review by the banks in the light of movements in costs. Any such changes are a matter for the commercial judgment of the banks themselves.

Permanent building societies are primarily a State rather than a Commonwealth responsibility. However I understand that, like savings banks, building societies do not generally charge customers for transactions on their deposit accounts.

(4) What are the proposals for synthetic fuel projects considered by the Board, and referred to in its report (p. 19), and, in particular, (a) what degree of discussions have been, or are, taking place to provide maximum local opportunities for the extraction and processing of these resources, (b) what is the nature of the synthetic fuel project in each case, (c) where is each project located, (d) what companies are involved, and (e) what conditions on technology transfer have been imposed.
(5) What degree of discussions have been, or are, taking place by the Board to provide maximum benefits from technology transfer in relation to other mineral resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Foreign investment proposals are examined under the Government's foreign investment policy on the basis of various criteria to assess whether they are in accord with Australia's national interest in terms of economic and other benefits. Where applicable, technology aspects of individual proposals are considered so as to assess whether the introduction of new technology would result in economic benefits to Australia. In considering this matter, regard is had to whether Australian investors would also be able to gain access to the relevant technology by entering commercial arrangements to purchase or lease it from overseas sources. In addition, proposals are examined to ascertain whether arrangements for the undertaking of research and development, and royalty, licensing and patent arrangements are in accord with Australia's interests.

In the Foreign Investment Review Board's 1981 annual report, technology transfer was referred to in relation to synthetic fuel projects. While the technology for converting raw materials into liquid fuels has been in existence for a long time, its refinement to suit the conversion of particular resource deposits on a commercial basis is not yet developed. Accordingly, the question of access for Australian investors to the relevant technological developments has been a major factor in examining major synthetic fuel projects between foreign and Australian interests.

The Board has therefore been concerned that, while keeping in mind the commercial circumstances involved, the technology arrangements between the parties should secure the maximum long term transfer of technology to Australia.

I have previously announced that, subject to consideration under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the proposals for possible future development of both the Rundle shale oil project and the Gelliondale coal liquefaction project will be given favourable consideration under the Government's foreign investment policy. Both proposals conform with the Government's policy objective of providing maximum opportunities for significant Australian participation in the extraction and processing of Australia's mineral resources.

Following examination by the Board of the proposed arrangements for technology associated with the Rundle project the Government considered that access would be provided to the participating Australian companies. In its consideration the Government has taken into account that technology arising from the project will be jointly owned by the participants, and the Australian partners will have access to other technology from the Esso group for use at Rundle and in other projects.

The conditions on technology transfer imposed for the Gelliondale project require the parties to submit to the Board for examination any technical agreements between the parties and the providers of any technology (whether related corporations or not). It is envisaged that once Arco has met its initial expenditure commitments to earn its interest in the venture, new technology arising from the project will be the joint property of the participants, while the Australian participants will have appropriate access to other technology provided by the Arco group.

In relation to the Nippon project, construction of the pilot plant has been approved under the foreign investment policy against the background of arrangements for co-operation on energy research and development between Australia and Japan. The Victorian and Australian authorities will have access to the technology. Should the project proceed beyond the pilot plant stage, the Government has required that Australians be offered 50 per cent equity and that they be afforded access to the technology arising from the pilot plant on reasonable terms and conditions.

To date, proposals relating to the Condor and Mitsui-CSR projects have been considered under the foreign investment policy only up to the feasibility study stage. Should proposals eventuate for the development of these projects to the demonstration or full commercial stage they will require separate examination by the Board for recommendatoin to the Government. At that time, the Board will seek from the parties the arrangements for the ownership of technology arising from the project, and for the transfer of other technology to the project.

(5) In relation to other mineral resources, the Government has recently re- affirmed its guidelines for at least 50 per cent Australian equity and control in new mining developments (other than for new uranium projects where the objective is 75 per cent Australian equity and Australian control). In addition, the Government has decided that, in the case of new devleopments in the minerals processing industry, it wishes to ensure that maximum opportunities are made available for significant Australian participation in ownership and control. In considering individual cases, the Government will seek to arrive at an appropriate level of Australian equity participation to meet this objective, in consultation with the parties. In this process recognition will continue to be given to the needs of such projects for relatively large amounts of capital, and in some cases for new or advanced technology not at present available from domestic sources, and to other special aspects which could affect the feasibility of Australian participation in a venture.

Matters relating to technology are not normally an issue in proposals relating to minerals extraction where the technology is already widely disseminated within the industry. However, where the technology involved may not always be generally available, for example in the petroleum industry and in minerals processing, access to the technology by the Australian participants is closely examined by the Board in its assessment of the net economic benefits to Australia. The Board seeks to ensure, wherever appropriate and commercially practicable, that the agreements and the arrangements involved in such projects provide scope for the Australian investors to have access to the technology, so as to encourage dissemination of the technology within Australia over the longer term.

Through the Foreign Investment Review Board, the Government has also drawn the attention of foreign investors to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises with which Australia has associated itself and which the Government wishes foreign interests operating in Australia to observe. Under the OECD Guidelines, multinational enterprises should contribute to the development of scientific and technological capacities of the countries in which they operate, including as far as appropriate the establishment and improvement in host countries of their capacity to innovate. They should also permit the rapid diffusion of technologies having regard to the protection of property rights, and transfer technology on reasonable terms and conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What reviews are made of designs of Australian coins and bank notes.
(2) Are any plans afoot for the re-designing of Australian currency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The move to decimal currency in 1966 involved the introduction of completely new designs for all notes and coins. Since that time there has been no general change in the design of currency on issue, and there is no present proposal to issue new series of coins. However, production of the round 50 cent silver coin was limited to the 1966 issue. This coin was replaced by a dodecagonal cupro-nickel coin in 1969. On several occasions, commemorative issues of this coin with special designs have also been made. The introduction, since 1966, of the $5 note and the $50 note and collector coins with face values of $10 and $200 have also, of course, involved new designs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Federal Government inquiries into the question of superannuation are under way at the moment and what are the terms of reference of each inquiry.
(2) Have any directions, either formal or informal, been passed on to each inquiry subsequent to the provisions of the terms of reference; if so, what were those directions.
(3) When is each inquiry expected to report to the Government.
(4) Will the findings of each inquiry be made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As the honourable member will be aware questions involving various aspects of superannuation arise on a continuing basis in the ordinary course of reviewing government policies in areas such as taxation, social welfare and industrial relations. It would appear that the Task Force on Occupational Superannuation, which has been undertaking inquiries into aspects of occupational superannuation, is the only general inquiry at the official level of relevance to the honourable member's question.

As indicated in my press statement of 12 July 1979 the Task Force on Occupational Superannuation was established to consider the role of occupational superannuation in providing for retirement and whether there is a need to revise or impose new standards for schemes. The Task Force was asked to make recommendations if existing standards were regarded as inappropriate and to examine the question of trade union involvement in superannuation schemes.

I would also refer the honourable member to the announcement made on 7 June 1982 by Mr David Connolly, MP, concerning the establishment of a Committee of backbenchers to examine current superannuation arrangements and possibilities as a result of a decision of the Government parties and its terms of reference were outlined in Mr Connolly's announcement of 7 June.

(2) In the early stages of its work the Task Force on Occupational Superannuation put forward a preliminary report and in the light of that report the Government agreed that a number of specific matters should form part of its work program. These matters were principally concerned with the formulation of possible arrangements for ensuring that superannuation funds which attract taxation concessions are used for genuine retirement purposes and observe improved operational standards (e.g., in the area of security of benefits) and with the examination of a number of other superannuation issues of relevance to taxation and social welfare policy.

(3) Subject to the outcome of processes currently in hand for further Ministerial guidance to be given to the Task Force, it is my expectation that the Task Force will be able to report to the Government later this year.

(4) I am not able to give any indication at this stage whether it would be appropriate for the findings of the Task Force to be made public. This is a matter which will be considered after the report of the Task Force has been received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have some investors been making tax free money by buying discounted Commonwealth Bonds, company debentures and semi-government loans and reaping a tax-free profit when the investment expires or matures.
(2) Does section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act make it clear that when something is bought with the intention of selling it at a profit it is taxable.
(3) Is it a fact that bonds are not sold, but expire or mature.
(4) What steps will be taken to ensure that this tax loophole is no longer available to investors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) I refer the honourable member to my Press release No. 134 of 23 July 1982.

It is the view of the Commissioner of Taxation that profits arising from the sale or redemption of securities purchased or acquired at a discount represent assessable income. The Government believes that the view held by the Commissioner is correct in law. Amendment to the income tax law to make these profits liable to tax is not necessary.

Nevertheless representations to the Government in recent weeks have clearly demonstrated that a significant number of small investors have purchased discounted securities in the bona fide belief that the profit on sale or redemption would not be regarded as assessable income. To some extent this belief may have been influenced by the fact that the tap stock prospectus contains no advice that the redemption discount is assessable income.

The Government has decided, therefore, to amend the income tax law to exempt from income tax profits made by investors on the redemption or sale of securities purchased at a discount before June 1982. The exemption will not apply to profits made by traders or dealers or that are profits to which sections 26AAA, 26C or 26 (a) apply.
